ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ARMOUR TRAINING CENTRE

(Explosion incident)

     1.  Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the Minister for Defence (a) what is the cause of the recent explosion incident at the Armour Training Centre at Sungei Gedong; and (b) whether safety measures have been followed.

     The Minister for Defence (RAdm Teo Chee Hean):   Mr Speaker, Sir, on 23rd February 2004, Active Training Wing (ATW) of Armour Training Centre (ATC) conducted a live firing at the range in Area 'D' as part of the unit's course syllabus to practise the gunners in their gunnery skills and knowledge.

 

     During the night live firing, at about 2000 hours, there was a stoppage in one of the 0.5 inch calibre Machine Guns.  The gunner carried out the prescribed immediate action drill, but was unable to rectify the stoppage.  The bolt of the gun was stuck in the forward position.  The Chief Safety Officer and the vehicle Safety Officer were informed of the incident, and tried unsuccessfully to rectify the problem.  The weapon was then left in-situ facing the range targets until the end of the live firing session.

 

     At the end of the live firing, the Chief Safety Officer and the vehicle Safety Officer tried again to rectify the problem, but were unsuccessful.  They mistakenly assessed that the weapon was clear of ammunition and deemed it safe to be brought back to the armoury in camp when, in fact, there was a round lodged in the chamber.

 

    At about 1100 hours on 24th February 2004, an Officer and three Specialists drew out the weapon from the armoury with the intent of rectifying the stoppage. 

Column: 552

They tried to rectify the jammed weapon without knowing that there was a round in the chamber.  In the course of doing so, there was an explosion in the chamber of the machine gun.

 

     The preliminary investigations ascertained the following:

 

    (a)        there was a current lesson plan for the conduct of the live firing, and the live firing at the range was conducted in accordance with the lesson plan.

 

     (b)        Incorrect procedures were adopted by the two Officers at the range to check whether the jammed weapon was free from any ammunition.

 

     (c)        The actions taken to rectify the jammed weapon after it was brought back to the unit were also incorrect.

 

     (d)        As regards medical coverage, there was proper medical coverage in the unit and the evacuation procedure was prompt and correct.

 

     Four servicemen, a Regular and three Full-time National Servicemen, were hurt as a result of this incident.  One of the National Servicemen was required to undergo an operation to remove fragments from his eyes sustained from the exploded weapon.  He has been discharged from the hospital, and is recuperating at home.  The remaining three servicemen sustained minor injuries and were treated as outpatients.  All four servicemen will have their medical condition reviewed by the medical specialists over time.

 

        A Board of Inquiry has since been convened to investigate the circumstances leading to this incident.  Disciplinary action will be taken against individuals found to be negligent or to have contravened the established procedures and safety regulations leading to this incident.

Column: 553

     Dr Ong Chit Chung (Jurong):  Sir, should the officer or men not send the defective weapon to the armourer or ammunition specialists?  What lessons can we draw from this particular incident, and can such lessons be incorporated into the training of our officers or men?

     RAdm Teo Chee Hean:  Sir, the correct procedure for dealing with such a situation is that if a gun stops and there is a round in the chamber or it is assessed that there is a possibility of a round in the chamber, the gun should be left in-situ.  The armourer should come to the range and clear the weapon and rectify the fault in-situ.  The officers incorrectly assessed that there was no round in the chamber which led to the string of events.

 

     Dr Ong is quite correct.  This is something which should continue to be stressed to the soldiers and officers.

HOME OWNERSHIP

(Policy changes)

     The following Question stood in the name of Mdm Ho Geok Choo -

    

     2.  To ask the Minister for National Development (a) what are some of the driving assumptions for policy changes with regard to home ownership; and (b) what will be the tipping point for his Ministry to recognise singles for absolute home ownership.

     Dr Ong Chit Chung:  Question No. 2, Sir.

     Mr Speaker:  The Minister who is replying is not here yet.  I will go to the next Question.

 

     Later ---

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for National Development): 

Column: 554

Mr Speaker, Sir, the objective of the public housing programme is to provide affordable housing for Singaporeans.  Home ownership remains the key mission of public housing, as it gives Singaporeans an asset and a stake in the nation.  As our home ownership policy is premised on the family as the basic unit of society, the existence of a family unit remains one of the basic eligibility conditions for the purchase of an HDB flat.  

    

     Over the last four decades, the Government has successfully housed more than 80% of Singaporeans in HDB estates, and enabled over 90% of Singapore households to become home-owners.  Nonetheless, there is still a need to provide for the housing needs of the new households that are formed each year, some of whom will have to turn to HDB for a flat.  The Government will ensure that affordable public housing continues to remain available to them. 

 

     Single citizens are considered as part of a family unit and are encouraged to live together with their families for mutual support and care.  Therefore, a single child forming a family unit with his parents is eligible to purchase any type of HDB flat. 

 

     At the same time, the Government recognises that there are some older Singaporeans who remain single and who prefer to live on their own.  To meet the housing needs of this group, HDB has implemented two housing schemes for citizen singles who are 35 years old or older.  Under the Joint Singles (JS) Scheme, two or more singles can jointly buy any type of resale flat, while under the Single Singapore Citizen (SSC) Scheme, a single can purchase a 3-room or smaller resale flat alone.  Eligible singles can also enjoy a housing grant of $11,000 or $22,000 under the Single Singapore Citizen Scheme and the Joint Singles schemes respectively.  

 

Column: 555

     Therefore, singles are already recognised under our home ownership policy.  We will continue to review our housing policies for singles regularly to ensure that they remain fair and relevant.

MOBILE PHONE FITTED WITH SPEAKING CUM LISTENING EXTENSION

(Use by driver of a vehicle)

     3.  Dr Tan Boon Wan asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will clarify whether the use of a mobile phone fitted with a speaking-cum-listening extension by the driver of a vehicle is permissible.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M) (for the Minister for Home Affairs):  Mr Speaker, Sir, currently, it is not an offence for drivers to use a hands-free kit, which is a speaking-cum-listening extension device to communicate while driving.   

 

      Nevertheless, I would advise drivers to use the phone with a hands-free kit attached only if they really have to.  They should also keep the calls as short as possible.  If they cannot keep their calls short, they should pull out of mainstream traffic or get another passenger to answer or make the call.

     Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio):  Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary if he will tell us whether it is an offence for a driver to hold a handphone in one hand and press the button on the keypad? 

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M:  Sir, under the Road Traffic Act, section 65B states that, "Any person who, being the driver of a motor vehicle on a road or a public place, uses a mobile telephone while the motor vehicle is in motion shall be guilty of an offence..."

Column: 556

     Dr Tan Boon Wan:  Further clarification.  What if he is using an extension device?  Would he still be committing an offence, in view of the Senior Parliamentary Secretary's explanation earlier?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M:  Yes, he will be.  If he is driving and one of his hands is holding the phone and using it, it is an offence.

     Dr Tan Boon Wan:  What is the offence?  Is it that he holds the wheel in one hand and presses the button with another hand, or just a mere using of the phone is an offence?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M:  The Member is referring to a driver who is driving a car which is in motion.  If he is not using the handphone, he does not have to hold it.  So, under normal circumstances, if you are holding your phone in one hand, it is regarded as using it, especially if you are seen pressing the buttons.

     Mr Speaker:  Last question, Dr Tan.

     Dr Tan Boon Wan:  I just wonder if a person is not using a handphone, but using one hand to drive, and uses his other hand to press a button on the sound system, for example, he is obviously using one hand and pressing a button.

     Mr Speaker:  Please stop wondering and ask your question, Dr Tan.

     Dr Tan Boon Wan:  Would that be an offence?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M:  Sir, currently, we can say that the use of handphone is one of the situations where a driver may take one of his hands off the wheels.  But there are other scenarios, like the Member has mentioned, but at the

Column: 557

moment they are not legislated as a specific offence like in the case of handphone.  So you can press the air-conditioner button and the other buttons.  Under the law, it is not an offence.

     Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang):  Sir, may I ask if the use of the handphone for viewing SMS messages while driving or sending such messages would also constitute an offence under the Road Traffic Act?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M:  Yes, Sir, it is an offence.  In fact, if you use the handphone and send SMS, I think you will be a lot more distracted from the road at the point of using it.  So, therefore, it constitutes an offence.

     Mr Speaker:  A final question, please.

     Dr Tan Boon Wan:  I would like to ask if we stipulate the conditions for use of the handphone with extension - because by the Senior Parliamentary Secretary's explanation the mere use of the handphone, whether with an extension or otherwise, constitutes an offence, and many people in fact use the handphone with the extension cord - are they committing an offence, by his definition?

     Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M:  Sir, I would say that if you happen to receive a call, you press the button and you have a hands-free kit, you can respond by speaking on the phone.  That, I think, is quite safe.  But if you let go one hand from the steering wheel and keep yourself busy with the handphone, you will be committing an offence.

     Mr Speaker:  Dr Tan, I think you have asked your questions and the Senior Parliamentary Secretary has already answered them.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT

 

      Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [27th February, 2004],

 

      “That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2004 to 31st March, 2005.” – [Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance].

 

     Question again proposed.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to start off this debate.

 

     After the Budget announcement by DPM Lee, our GPC for Finance, Trade and Industry conducted a dialogue session with the members of our Resource Panel and representatives from the chambers of commerce and trade associations.  The participants gave us very valuable and pertinent feedback.  My GPC colleagues and I shall be raising many issues and suggestions proffered by them during this Budget debate as well as during the Committee of Supply debate.  Our GPC wishes to sincerely thank all the participants for their contributions in the dialogue.

 

     This year's Budget is said to be a continuation of past years' budgets.  To some extent, this is true.  As declared in past Budget announcements, the Government would implement the 2% cut of corporate tax by 2005, and it is implemented.  In previous Budgets, the statements mainly covered the details of the Government's revenues and expenditures, before rounding up with the tax and fiscal policies and changes.  However, what I find significantly different in this

year's Budget is the extensive coverage of the non-budget topics,  including the Government's long-term plans on the three main pillars of Singapore, which are effective Government, strong society and land of

Column: 559

opportunity.  In this regard, I view this year's Budget as a very important milestone document, and the plans of the Government in the medium and long term are outlined at some length.  It is not a mere short-term annual Budget announcement.  It therefore reads almost like the Presidential Address at the start of each session of Parliament.  The subjects are wide ranging and have long-term implications.

 

     Since this year's Budget not only touches on budget and tax matters, but covers societal issues and portrays Singapore as a land of opportunity, I shall therefore set out my comments in the same sequence as in the Budget, that is, in the order of (1) effective Government; (2) strong society; and (3) land of opportunity.  With the stated plans on these three key pillars, the crux of the matter is how can the Government bring all the people along this path of well-being, wealth, and enlightenment in the land of opportunity.  Carrying everybody along is going to be a monumental task to reach this fabulous promised land.  The question is how to get there.

 

     First, on effective Government.  On the first pillar on effective Government, DPM Lee has enunciated the means to attain effective Government, which is through sound public finance, living within our means and service delivery.  However, I feel that the basic tenet of effective Government is mainly the people - people make the Government and the civil service.  Therefore, we need to have both strong Government leaders as well as an effective civil service.  All great plans and great schemes will come to nought if there is a weak or corrupt government and ineffective and bungling civil servants.

 

    I believe the next step is how to remake the civil service such that it is

Column: 560

enterprising, innovative and ready to consider and accept new ideas and new approaches.  Getting good people in the civil service is therefore of fundamental importance.  Generally, we agree that Singapore has an enviable strong civil service.  As Mr Ngiam Tong Dow, a respected retired top civil servant, said:  "In our years of budgetary abundance, we have often mistaken form for substance ... headquarters of Ministries and statutory boards, have been built to heights of elegance more than what their functions require ...  As I drive by these gleaming glass palaces, I often wonder whether the learning, teaching and research match the grandeur of the buildings ... in old Fullerton Building described as dark and dim.  Its saving grace was that there were some bright minds working in it."  I think we need to remake the civil service.  There is a need for mindset change. 

 

     In recent years, initiatives like the "Pro-enterprise Panel" and "Cut Waste Committee" have resulted in drawing the civil servants closer to the reality of the ground sentiments.  Civil servants are rectifying some of the adverse results of Government rules and practices.  However, I am still disappointed that often, when faced with a certain new idea or appeal for flexibility on the application of rules which they cannot handle, the civil servants would often fall back on a convenient refrain: "If I allow you this flexibility of rule, then I have to allow everybody else."  My retort is that if the rule change is good for my case, what is then wrong for it to be made applicable for all cases?  This will be met with a finality: "No, no, no.  We cannot do that.  It would be rather chaotic then."  As a result, a great idea is killed.

 

More interactions with the ground

 

     Sir, I think that what we need is to get the mighty civil servants to come down from their ivory tower and have more

Column: 561

opportunity to mix with the ground.  I believe the Government is already doing that.  Perhaps just not enough.

 

     I recall that many years ago, when I was doing my MBA in Insead, France, my Japanese coursemate told me one day in elation that he had been assigned to take care of the Christmas tree decorations back in the office, when he returned for the Christmas holiday.  I was surprised, as decorating the Christmas tree was a menial task.  But my Japanese friend said: "No, our present Chairman had also been assigned to the task of taking care of the Christmas tree when he was a junior officer.  Hence, being given this task is of great importance and significance!"  Actually, by being involved in such a mundane task, he had the opportunity to understand ground sentiments of the company better.  I think it is time for our top civil servants to come down from their high chairs and try their hand at decorating the Christmas tree!

 

     I suggest that it should be made an essential part of their training that civil servants should spend some time in an overseas assignment (for example, in India, China or elsewhere), as well as spend some time in an operational enterprise or even the private sector to enable them to have a more rounded experience and exposure. 

 

      I am particularly heartened to read in the recent Straits Times series on "Recruit - Scholars' Choice 1 to 3".  I read the Friday, 5th March 2004, report of the typical example of Mr Simon Ng, aged 26.  He is a recipient of the Overseas Merit Scholarship awarded by the PSC.  After three years at the Imperial College, London, and a year at Stanford University in USA, he went on to spend another year working in China.  This wide experience had moved him up the intellectual, cultural and personal levels.  There are numerous other examples of such scholars, like Mr Simon Ng, who are getting excellent all-

Column: 562

rounded exposure.  I think it bodes well for our civil service to have such an excellent crop of future recruits.

 

Creating "Bureaupreneurs" out of current corps of civil servants

 

      However, I am not sure whether our current crop of middle and senior civil servants has gone through enough of such multi-faceted exposure.  The world is fast changing and fast moving.  If we want to remake Singapore, we have also got to remake the civil service.  We need civil servants who are responsive, innovative and prepared to accept change.  Perhaps, instead of calling them "bureaucrats", we can coin a new term for them to insert an "entrepreneurial" element in it.  Maybe, we can call them "bureaupreneurs" - people who can turn the civil service into an enterprising and responsive organisation.

 

Butterfly Effect

 

     Sir, I am supportive of DPM Lee's intention to permanently cut by 2% the budget caps of all Ministries, except MINDEF, in FY 2004 and another 2% in FY 2005.  This is a very commendable move indeed.  However, I just wish to forewarn DPM Lee of the "Butterfly Effect" of such a small 2% cut.  There is now a popular movie in the cinemas by the same name "Butterfly Effect".  The Effect propounds the chaos theory, that the fluttering of the wings of a butterfly in, say,  Africa, could cause a chain effect a month later that affects a tornado in USA, in another part of the world.  An interesting theory.

 

     By the Butterfly Effect in the Government budget, I mean to watch out for the rippling repercussions of the 2% cut through the Ministries. The small cut could end in very huge and some strange and diverse results.  The 2% cut may look very innocuous, but this cut starting at one end of the Ministry's budget may

Column: 563

result in multiple thousand cuts down the line in the operating agencies.  I am more concerned that down the line, some very small but important social projects for the community or the poor may get chopped as a result.

 

     Hence, I truly do not wish to see that the 2% cut for 2004 and another 2% for 2005 for each Ministry will result in numerous small cuts which are crucial in some meaningful and supportive projects for certain welfare organisations and programmes.

 

"Hurry to Wait" Syndrome 

 

     Next, I like to warn about the "Hurry to Wait" syndrome in the civil service.  It might well happen if we do not watch closely.  This is similar to the resultant phenomenon during each year's National Day Parade where most participants call it "Hurry to Wait".  What it means is that while participants (some could be just young primary school children) are taking part in the 15-minute event in the Parade, say, at 7.00 pm, but because the commanders and the persons in charge want to be trebly sure that the participants are not late, each level of instruction adds 15 to 30 minutes of buffer time.  By the time the designated time is given to the participants, they usually need to be at the Stadium by 3.00 pm in the afternoon.  They are then "Hurried to Wait".  It creates inefficiency and unnecessary inconvenience.

 

Differentiate between citizens and PRs

 

     Moving on to strong society, one of the major tenets of a strong society is a strong citizenry.  By strong citizenry, I mean Singaporeans who have a strong love for their country, they have deep-rooted sentiments to preserve and protect the country, they have the care and concern for their fellow Singaporeans. 

Column: 564

Naturally, such deep-rooted attachments cannot be fostered overnight.  Singaporeans are very pragmatic people.  If we want them to be proud Singaporeans, we should have a visible and definitive gap between the benefits of being citizens versus the benefits of being PRs.

 

Better recognition and compensation for National Servicemen

 

     Currently, many Singaporeans said they do not feel any better than the PRs, who live here and enjoy equal benefits of a clean and well-run city.  In fact, many Singaporeans feel that they are disadvantaged due to the fact that legally, they themselves and their children have to do full time national service.  They also have to do the yearly obligatory reservist stints thereafter.

 

     NSF and reservists do affect young Singaporeans' career advancement.  They fall behind non-Singaporean colleagues by 2 1/2 years of seniority, their yearly reservist disruptions are frowned upon by employers.  These are major sacrifices of male Singaporeans.  To compensate, I would like to suggest that the Government should do a review of the salaries and compensations of NSF and reservists.  Currently, NSF servicemen are relatively poorly paid.  At least, they are less paid than their regular counterparts.  So, why not equalise or narrow the gap between the pay of the reservists and the regulars, or the NSF and the regulars?  Secondly, an arrangement should be put in place to recognise the 2 1/2 years of NSF as a seniority and annual increment comparison with non-Singaporean staff, in both the civil service and in the private sector.

 

     I believe more could be done to demonstrate the benefits of Singapore citizens amply exceed those of PRs.  The Government can set down the various benefits of Singaporeans, in terms of

Column: 565

housing, medical, education, immigration and various other citizens' rights.  Besides the definable benefits, which I call the pull factors, we should also look at the intangible issues of "push factors".  Why are many Singaporeans emigrating?  Some people said that they find Singapore too stifling and cloistered up.  Is it true?  There are numerous jokes about Singaporeans who do not open their mouths.  We must do some honest introspection.  Does merely allowing bar top dancing and reverse bungee jumps open up the sense of restrictive environment?  What more can be done?

 

Dual citizenship

 

     Should we not revive the proposal to allow dual citizenship?  Many countries which are open minded and progressive allow dual citizenship.  Is there a genuine risk that allowing dual citizenship will facilitate the flight of good and capable Singaporeans, especially in time of crisis?  Is that risk more of a function of how much we have ingrained into our young Singaporeans the sense of pride and love of the country?  Would the benefit of dual citizenship outweigh the perceived risks?

 

     I think I have been hesitant in the past about allowing dual citizenship.  But now, I am thinking otherwise.   With the more mobile and mass communication in the new world, Singaporeans with ability and talent will always be the target of foreign countries.  Therefore, allowing them dual citizenship will in fact allow them to retain ties with Singapore.  Conversely, allowing dual citizenship will enable us to attract more foreigners to take up citizenship, particularly when we have only 1.26 fertility replacement rate.

 

     Dual citizenship should be a sacred cow that is worth taking a relook.  In the past, matters such as dual citizenship and casinos in Singapore are spoken about in hush tones in quiet corners, as though it is a great heresy to voice such subjects. 

Column: 566

Raising these subjects imply lack of patriotism.  It should not be.  I personally do not support the idea of casino in Singapore, but I think the dual citizenship idea deserves a relook.

 

Joining privileges of the Singapore Club

 

     We have to show to the PRs the plentiful benefits of being a Singaporean.  It is quite a package of both tangible benefits and intangible attractions.

These are so-called joining privileges.  Being Singaporean should mean joining an "exclusive club".  The target is to make it such that everybody is vying to join this "Singapore Club".

 

     Whilst we want to attract more people to become Singaporeans, we must be mindful not to alienate certain segments of the people.  As our society progresses, it is inevitable that some groups may feel marginalised.  These are the poor, aged and under-privileged.  There should be adequate attention and resources allocated to help these groups.  Remember my earlier point about the "Butterfly Effect"?  Do make sure that the 2% cut in budgets does not result in some benefits going to these groups being curtailed.  The butterfly effect may cause some down-trodden people to be axed, if we are not careful.

 

Care for the marginalised segments

 

     In fact, besides the old, aged and underprivileged, I wish to voice my concern on a special group.  These are the people in the 45-62 or so age group.  They face an impact of treble whammies.  First, those in this group will have their CPF reduced.  Second, they may face pay cuts or retrenchments.  Third, they will face higher medical and hospitalisation costs as they grow old.

 

     Many professionals in their 50s find that, because of changing circumstances, they are replaced or retrenched.  Most of

Column: 567

them are still able-bodied, with good minds and wide experience.  They have some good years to run.  Many are not finding employers who are prepared to give them full-time employment.  As a fall-back and to preserve their dignity and pride, they go around carrying a card saying they are consultants.  I strongly urge the Government to think of some schemes or mechanism to help the people in this group.  Perhaps, there can be a central agency.  This agency can match their professional skills and experience against prospective clients.  The clients may need certain of these professionals on an ad-hoc or contractual basis.  These professionals can be tasked to lead or join in local and overseas assignments.  This pool of senior executives is growing.  We have to find means to ensure that this useful and substantial resource pool is not put to waste.

 

Procreation policies

 

     A major part of the Budget Speech is devoted to the problem of procreation.  Our Total Fertility Rate (TFR) has fallen to 1.26, below that of many foreign established nations.  It is widely acknowledged that procreation and how to encourage young couples to marry earlier and have children earlier is a very complex and emotive issue.  It requires a holistic approach.  It is a big subject.  I hear that many MPs will touch on this, especially our lady MPs.  One report said that Dr Lily Neo has 28 ideas on how it could be done.  Let us hear from her.  Given such wide interest, I do not intend to dwell too deeply into this subject.  Let this space be given to other more qualified persons, especially our female counterparts, to debate on it. 

 

     I just wish to reflect on some concerns of employers that if we were to increase maternity leave to a longer period of six months, there is the worry of employers

Column: 568

that besides heavier salary costs, there is the added problem of disruption to work schedules and of staff covering duties.  This is an aspect that Mr Lim Hng Kiang and his study team have to consider when coming out with their recommendations.

 

Land of opportunity

 

     In his Budget Speech, DPM Lee stated that he sensed palpable optimism in the market.  This view, in the short term, may be correct.  In fact, all of us wish it so.  However, I am not sure whether the same can be said of the medium and long term. Is there palpable optimism in the medium and long term?  I think we do not know yet.

 

Look overseas for the land of gold?

 

     I like very much the heading of the third pillar as the "Land of Opportunity".  How many Singaporeans truly feel Singapore is or will become a land of opportunity?  In a land of opportunity, our streets should be paved with gold.  In typical Singlish, some may retort: "Where got gold?"

 

     Nowadays, we hear many Singapore businessmen saying that doing business and making money in Singapore is difficult.  Not really, as some are still making money, but many truly find the going difficult.  Several have resorted to going overseas to China, India and other parts of Southeast Asia to find their fortunes.  It is very ironical.  In the olden days, our forefathers came from China and India to seek their opportunities here.  After over 100 years, the tide is reversed.  Singaporeans are going to India and China to seek their fortunes.  Things do move in cycles.  There is an apt Chinese saying: "feng shui lun lui zhuan". 

 

     With the changing of times, the diminishing reliance on clan associations, tontine funds and trade associations, and the move to rationalise the banks and

Column: 569

finance houses, there are increasingly fewer avenues for the people in temporary need of funds to get help.  Many went to loan sharks as a result.  As graphically depicted in a scene in the movie "Money No Enough", one loan shark in the movie proudly proclaimed that he was providing a much-needed service to the community of providing loans to the poor, which our banks would not do.  I would like the Government to consider seriously how more forms of financial help and related assistance can be given to the poor and unemployed to tide them over their temporary troubles so that they would not get into more troubles by borrowing from loan sharks and the like.

 

Honour the self-help groups and VWOs

 

     Could the self-help groups do more and reach out deeper into the community to target these desperately poor?  I do not mean to lend them money like the loan sharks, but to give them aid in terms of food provisions, temporary job assistance, retraining, transport, schooling expenses, and such like.  On this note, I truly wish to commend the NTUC Fairprice for recently giving out food vouchers to be distributed via the grassroots organisations to the poor and needy.  We can encourage more to be done by social and community groups like the Lions Club, Rotary Club and other voluntary welfare organisations to step forward.  Encourage more thrift and loan cooperatives to be formed to fill in the vacuum left by the banks and finance houses mergers.  Those who give generous donations should be recognised, eg, VWOs and social volunteers as well as philanthropists may be considered for National Day Awards.   

 

     Perhaps, it is time to review whether we should continue to assign the major and centralised fund-raising effort to Community Chest.  This has a dilutive effect on the choice and target groups of each charity to source for its own

Column: 570

donations.  It also weakens the strength of each charitable body to go out and seek donations on its own.  This is a matter that perhaps MCDS may wish to review.

 

Pro-competition - help the small businesses

 

     In the Budget Speech, DPM Lee said that the primary stance of the Government in its economic policy is pro-competition.  I would like to voice a view that this policy cannot be taken to the extreme.  Singapore is a small country.  Our market is very small to carry this policy of pro-competition in every arena.  I would advocate a degree of flexibility.  It is a fact that we have openly and unabashedly given long years of protection to the local banks.  The constant crying for help by SMEs cannot be crying wolf all the time.  At times, they are really in need of help, for example, in getting some preferential treatment in certain types of non-strategic and non-critical Government procurement contracts.  It is practised in many countries, even in the USA.  It is also time to recognise that GLCs do occupy some of the business space in Singapore and they compete against SMEs.  The GLCs tend to leverage on their size and connections.

 

     We know that this is a pro-business Government, which is done for national benefit.  Nobody denies that.  There has been some disappointment that this year's Budget is again too pro-MNCs and pro-large local companies.  For example, the pioneer status for foreign investors is increased from 10 years to 15 years.  When the Government does give something to small local companies like start-ups, it only gives parsimoniously and grudgingly.  Let me demonstrate why.

 

     The Budget announced that local start-up companies are given a new tax relief of $100,000 of profits over the first three

Column: 571

years of operation.  This incentive is not of much help.  Most new companies struggle to make money in the first few years.  Those which can make profits in the first few years are in the minority.  So, why offer an incentive that most local companies cannot enjoy?  It is like dangling a plum in front of them to merely tease them.   I would like to suggest that the Government consider varying the scheme to allow for companies to enjoy the first $100,000 profit offset as from the point of the first year of profit of a new start-up, ie, first year of profit, not in the first three years alone.  If we can be so generously giving 15 years of tax-free status to MNCs, why not a small gesture for these small new start-ups?

 

Help the individuals

 

     Another complaint, Sir, is: why is the Government more generous to companies as against the individuals?  The Government is favouring corporations versus individuals in the 2% income tax cut.  The Government has said that it cannot fulfill its promised 2% cut to 20% target for both corporate and individuals at the same time due to budget constraints.  If so, why not share the misery between corporations and individuals?  Why not allow for a 1% cut each in both the corporate and personal income taxes, rather than give all the 2% cut to corporations and then ask the individuals to wait for a few more years?

 

Towards a more open society

 

     Sir, to achieve the end of creating Singapore as a land of opportunity, it is very valid that we must have effective government and strong society.  Effective government is easier to achieve, but strong society is much harder.  The two routes to creating a strong society are either to create steadfastness and

Column: 572

homogeneity, or flexibility and diversity.  In the old world, I think steadfastness and homogeneity could work.  But, in modern Singapore, where we have mass instant communication with the outside world, I firmly believe that flexibility and diversity are the right choice.  I strongly feel that to create a strong society, we should encourage people to open up and speak up more freely.  Any stone is worth turning over now and then for a re-look.  There can be gems underneath.  At the most, if it is not time yet, we can place the stone back gently.

 

     Hence, we must allow the establishment of a more open society.  There is a saying that great men think alike.  In the new world, great men do not have to think alike.  No one and no country has the monopoly to great ideas.  In many instances, it is quite valid that "the unreasonable man maketh the world".

 

     I am heartened that we are indeed moving towards this direction.  Over the weekend, it was reported in the newspapers that the Acting Education Minister, Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam, wishes the Ministry of Education to focus on how to nurture original thinkers.  He said:

 

     "We will not succeed if we produce young Singaporeans who are too regular, or too much of the same mould ...  We need Singaporeans with different talents and different ways of thinking ... willing to test new ideas and approaches with each other and with people from the world ... We have to nurture more Singaporeans who want to do something exceptional and stand out from the crowd."

 

     I fully agree with Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam.  Blessed would be the day when he could achieve his aim.  Let us not summarily dismiss ideas.  Let us have more open debates.  Let us find what we can learn from others, or strike out on our own. 

 

Column: 573

     Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to conclude by quoting a Chinese saying by a famous Tang dynasty poet called Wang Le:  "wu hua tian bao, ren jue ti ling".  It means to describe a fertile place where precious assets and talented minds can flourish.  We hope that Singapore can be such a place, a land of opportunity, a fertile place of men of talents.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, the previous speaker has trawled the whole Budget Statement, so I do not think I can compete with him to cover all the other points.  I promise to be short in my case.

 

     This year's Budget is pro-business, and there is little for the middle-income and lower-income households.  Corporate tax has been reduced to 20%.  This is welcome by all businessmen in Singapore.  However, personal income tax remains at 22%, with a promise from the Government that the personal income tax rate shall eventually be reduced to 20%.  I hope the delay shall not be too long.

 

     As regards the lowering of the corporate tax to 20%, whether it is sufficient incentive for those MNCs which are already here to remain here and to attract more new ones to come to our shores to do business, is another matter, because MNCs can now go elsewhere

Column: 574

where land and operating costs are cheaper than those in Singapore.  The challenge is for the Government to keep costs down.  Rentals in certain sectors, especially in the food and retail sectors, are still very high.  At my last meet-the-people session, an applicant

complained that he and his wife had to pay monthly rentals and service charges amounting to $10,000 for a food stall at a shopping mall in Yishun. I thought to myself: Singapore is supposed to be a first world country and people here still have to slog for 16 hours a day, seven days a week and 52 weeks a year, except probably for four days of respite during the Chinese New Year.  I thought that only workers in the third world countries have to work that long hours to earn a living.

 

     For a start, I call on the Government, which is the biggest landlord in Singapore, to set an example by lowering rentals of their properties to a fair rent, especially to people who carry out food business in Singapore, hoping that other landowners can follow suit.  High cost in doing business in Singapore has its problems.  The Government says that foreign direct investments are still attracted to Singapore at about $9 billion a year, but only to open up mostly high-tech industries which are not labour-intensive. This means that they do not employ that many workers. Those workers who are unemployed shall not be very happy when they learn that fewer jobs shall be created. At the moment, the unemployment rate in Singapore remains at about 4.5% or about 800,000 workers. The Government looks to the service sector to mitigate the unemployment problem. 

 

     The Budget Statement says that the Government is developing established services, such as trading and logistics, info-communications, technologies, financial services and tourism, while trying to expand emergent services such as education, healthcare and the creative

Column: 575

sectors. As far as I can see, Singapore should have no problems expanding the education and the healthcare sectors. We have the infrastructure and the talent to make Singapore the education centre and the health hub of the region.  We may have already become the education centre and the health hub of the region.  Healthcare costs in Singapore are too high and we may lose out to other countries in the region who are quickly learning from Singapore to establish hospitals to compete with us.  We, of course, must make sure that we do not lose out to them. 

 

     As for developing a vibrant creative sector in Singapore, I have not much confidence in that, after over 30 years of strict PAP rule, the majority of Singaporeans have become compliant, obedient and docile which are not conducive to establish the creative sector, in particular, the film industry. Hong Kong and America are more open and liberal societies than Singapore and they have successfully built a vibrant, successful film industry there which employs hundreds of workers and gives them lucrative returns. Singapore can also establish a successful film industry if we are willing to open our society and to be more liberal.  I hope that I can see that day come about.

 

     I shall briefly mention the procreation policy.  Last year, our TFR dropped to the lowest in the world, at 1.26.  We had only 36,000 births and we require something like 50,000 babies to replace ourselves. The big question is what is to be done.  Many suggestions had been forwarded and most probably are all valid. However, I would like to draw the Government's attention to the complaints of mothers with multiple births. Apparently, from the letters written to the local press recently, they have been unfairly discriminated against.  I wish the

Column: 576

Government could look seriously at their complaints and to try to put things right for them. I know they are only in the minority but the fact that the Government goes out of its way to help them, other mothers will take note that the Government is really sincere in helping mothers to have more babies and that will give mothers in Singapore more confidence. Who knows, the birth rate will climb in Singapore!  I appeal to the Government to look into the complaints of mothers with multiple births to make sure that they are not discriminated against.

 

     On foreign maids, the Government imposes a tax of $345 for each foreign maid employed in Singapore.  I would like to suggest that the Government uses part of that large sum of money collected as levy to employ qualified psychiatrists to carry out compulsory psychiatric screening of each maid before she can start work in Singapore.  This is to ensure that every maid who works in Singapore is psychologically sound. We have read of maids killing the child she is made to take care of, or even recently, a case was reported that a maid, together with another friend, also a maid, killed her own employer. Such murders are probably committed by maids who are not psychologically sound.  Those mentally sick maids, when under stress in their jobs, can break down psychologically and can commit violent acts or even murders. Therefore, to prevent such crimes, the Government should use part of the levy collected to screen those maids who wish to work in Singapore and declare them sound before they can take up a job here.  I think that would be money really worth spending.

Can I ask if he is also like that?  Is he experiencing that himself?  Otherwise, how can he make such a sweeping statement?

Whatever comes into our heads, with new ideas, we are willing to express those ideas in terms of art.  Most Singaporeans do not seem to do that.  I have given the reason why we are not creative.

     Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate.

 

    Sir, I support the motion. First of all, I would like to say that I had very low expectations of the types of initiatives the Finance Minister would be announcing in this Budget, given that the economy is at the recovery stage. Against these lower expectations, I am, in fact, pleased with the range of initiatives the Finance Minister announced this year, particularly

Column: 578

in the area of entrepreneurship support.  I now feel very comfortable that the Government is well on its way to making entrepreneurship an important agenda of our economic development.  Of course, the first signal of its seriousness was the appointment of the Minister in charge of Entrepreneurship, Mr Raymond Lim, and with its support of the many initiatives recommended to promote entrepreneurship, it gives many of us, who have been advocates of an entrepreneurial economy, confidence that we finally have the 'ears' of the Government, which, up to recently, looked like a half-hearted support. 

 

    Some of the initiatives which the Finance Minister announced, like the Entrepreneurship Investment Incentive, the tax changes to support asset securitisation and the tax benefits for start-ups were all moves in the right direction.  Before I go on, Sir, I would like to say that recently, I was asked by a journalist as to what I will be bringing up during the Budget debate.  I mentioned to him the issues that I would be raising and he told me that it was actually a waste of time and it was pointless, as the Government did not seem to listen.  I would like to state here that I disagree with this observation as I have, over the years, seen significant improvements put in place as a result of the suggestions made by many of us in this House and by other advocates of changes from the private sector and from organisations like the Action Committee for Entrepreneurs (ACE).  I am very happy to see the three initiatives supporting entrepreneurship I mentioned. These have been the recommendations that have been made by many of us and they are finally being implemented.  Of course, they were not implemented the day we asked for them but, over time, they happen. I would like to say, like any entrepreneur, never give up. We will continuously bring up those issues.  We will be spontaneous, as Mr Chiam wants us to be, and while we are

Column: 579

obedient, we will still come up with suggestions for changes.  This is one thing that really needs to happen, that is, a Government to listen a lot more because, as the results have shown, over time, what many of us said has turned out to be something that should have been done and, if the Government could implement this faster, we would have a more interesting economic development ahead of us.

 

    Sir, the one area that the Finance Minister glaringly missed out this year was in the area of helping local companies, not start-ups, but those SMEs who are already in business here. Instead of helping these companies, in fact, we added costs, with the increase in the ceiling for the SDF and the increase in the skilled workers' levy.  The private sector, particularly the SMEs, felt left out this time - that we did not address cost reduction issues. These are the few things that I would like to bring up this year.

 

    First of all, the area of cost reduction and business costs.  As I mentioned, this was really missing this year.  We have been hearing statements from the Government that the cost reduction efforts and the cost issues continue to plague the Singapore economy.  The only one thing that has been addressed in this respect is the area of wage restructuring

which is important to make Singapore companies competitive.  But the question is what is the root cause of these high wages in the first place?  Many of us have raised this many times, ie, the cost of living continues to be high, that every Singaporean here needs to have wages high enough to support even their basic lifestyle.  What is more, Singaporeans at this stage should expect better than the basic lifestyle, but the costs are just too high.  So, if we want to restructure wages, we must also restructure the cost of living in Singapore.  For companies to

Column: 580

remain competitive, there needs to be a restructuring of cost for businesses too.  So, may I ask the Finance Minister: what has happened to the cost reduction effort?

 

     I was afraid that at the first sign of a recovering economy the Government will forget about the need to do more about restructuring and reducing costs.  While there is a realisation by the Government, and my impression is that we have run out of ideas about what needs to be done, I think this could be quite detrimental to the economy.  I know of my local companies which still suffer from cost competitiveness as compared to their competitors around the world, particularly from around the region, and they risk going out of business.  Also, there are still a number of multinationals based here in Singapore who will not slow down their plans to relocate out of Singapore as they still do not see long-term cost reduction actions.  I have brought this up many times before about the Government's approach of temporary rebates and subsidies, which will result in the cost going up again once the Government decides that times are good again.  We, therefore, seriously need to look at long-term cost reduction and assurances from the Government that costs will go down or will remain low. 

 

     I would like to remind the Finance Minister about the seriousness of this issue and it was also raised by none other than the Senior Minister, Mr Lee Kuan Yew, who at one of his speeches published in the Business Times on 31st January 2004, headlined "Cost too high in Singapore".  The report quoted the Senior Minister as saying, "While the economy may be bouncing back, Singapore still has a long-term problem of high cost structure to deal with."  In his speech, he said, "Wages, rents, fees, taxes, have become too high compared to not only China and India, but also to our immediate neighbours.  Singapore requires basic

Column: 581

changes in cost structures and, unless this happens, many industries here will relocate to China and elsewhere."  So, again, I ask the Government not to relax too soon at the first sign of the economy recovering.  We need to seriously address these issues and to take this opportunity of good times to go about seriously addressing and reducing costs further.

 

     And what are the areas that we should look for? These have been brought up many times before and I would repeat them here.  First of all, permanent rental reductions, as well as lowering industrial and commercial property prices, to be benchmarked not against the commercial value of, say, Raffles City property, as what we have heard Mr Ngiam Tong Dow recently talked about the benchmarking approach that we have taken.  I think we should be benchmarking against the prices of properties in our competitor countries.  On utilities, while the energy market is being relaxed and it is coming down, I think it is not the most competitive in the area of power supply and also in other utilities.  So we need to address these as we move forward. 

 

     There are many other costs like hidden taxes - as I have mentioned before, the many taxes that we have, higher port and aviation charges - in fact, have seen us losing our business from Singapore to our neighbouring ports because of this issue.  The bottom-line is that the Government has yet to do a good job in addressing the cost competitiveness issues other than the good job it has done in the area of wage reduction, which is, of course, at the expense of harder times for Singaporeans if the rest of the cost issues are not addressed.

 

     The second area which is related to cost is one of cost of Government.  This is an area that surprised me that we seem to be operating in a "Fantasyland" where it continues to operate as if the economy is growing at a 10% rate.  We have seen,

Column: 582

since 1997, that this can no longer remain the case.  Why do I say "fantasy"?  While I mentioned the part on the cost of business problem and in the area of high charges and rates which the Government charges to businesses, I understand the principle of cost recovery, which is good, since this principle assumes that the Government would not make a profit when charging the people and the companies, and with the hope to keep such costs low.  But, if the cost of providing these services is high in the first place, then there is little hope for us in reducing costs to the users.  In this respect, I feel that the Government has not done enough to reduce its own costs.

 

     While I was encouraged by the Finance Minister's comments that the Cut Waste Panel has made progress, and about the efforts to limit the budgets of the various Ministries, I am not convinced enough has been done to reduce the cost of running the Government.  This was the hunch that I had because I have yet to see the cost coming down in these areas.  I went back to the past five years of the Budget books and I looked at the details.  To my surprise, the data shows that the cost of running the Government had continuously increased since 1999.  If we look at only the running cost items, not counting the development expenditures, which are capital and long-term investments in nature, the line items called "running cost" had continued to rise from $13.59 billion in 1999 to $17.05 billion in 2002.  Then it is estimated to be at $17.35 billion in 2003 and planned to be $18.05 billion in 2004.  Now, if we take out the military spending, which is strategic in nature, then the numbers under the operating expenditure section of the Budget book looks like this: all non-military expenditure in 1999 was $1.89 billion, and this continues to go up, with the $2.38 billion expected in 2004.  And, if I look at the manpower cost part of the Budget book, in 1999 the cost was $2.87 billion and this continues to go up

Column: 583

to a planned  $3.47 billion in 2004.  In fact, if my analysis is not wrong, then the 2004 cost of running the Government would be the highest in our recent history.

 

     These numbers surprised me, as I said, and therefore I think that we really need to get out of this fantasy world, because the whole world has changed around us in the last five years, particularly after the Asian financial crisis.  I have been involved in a number of companies and have been looking at what was happening around in the private sector.  In the real world, particularly in the private sector, they have restructured themselves and many companies have to do drastic cost reduction just to survive.  We have seen many companies in the private sector reducing cost by as much as 20-30% over the last two years.  In contrast, we are seeing the cost of Government continuing to go up and, therefore, there is little wonder that we continue to see business cost not coming down. 

 

     While we did well in wage reductions, who contributed to this?  They were the people of Singapore.  The companies have played their part too, and I feel it is now time for the Government to play its part seriously.  I think there is an urgent need for the Government to put in place cost reduction targets for the sake of boosting our economy.  Unless clear targets are set, like what the Senior Minister suggested, as a 20% cost reduction target for Singapore Airlines, that was what he said, I do not think any serious cost reduction would take place in the Government.  The Cut Waste Panel would have limited success because it just looks at wastes.  What the Government really needs to look at are real structural changes, which may not be obvious as wastes, but which can be structural changes and which can be re-engineered to achieve big improvements.

     In the area of cost, the Government needs to play its part too.  It should learn how the private sector got more productive and more efficient.  The companies which restructured their costs survive and they became stronger.  We need, therefore, the Government to be also productive and efficient and to become stronger.

 

     The one thing related to the issue of cost of Government is the issue of budget deficit which we have been talking about.  First of all, the budget deficits of the past years were really a result of specific transfers which the Government made for various reasons.  And, some of them were very good reasons.  At the operating level, we have not really seen a budget deficit.  The real deficit was really in the year 2003, where, before transfers, the deficit was about $1.16 billion.  In fact, at the operating level in 2004, we would still not see a deficit budget.  In fact, there is a surplus of $0.16 billion.  In any case, my real point is that there are two ways to balance a budget.  The first, of course, is to bring in more revenue, which is in a way not controllable.  While we have fixed taxes, companies may not make profits, individuals may not make income to pay taxes. But, the second way is to reduce costs.  So, if the Government can really work harder in reducing cost, I am sure we will have a surplus budget.  I think this again needs to be addressed quite seriously.

 

     Sir, the third area is one of the Government's interference and dominant role in GLCs and TLCs.  I feel that the Government should shed its "I know best" attitude when it comes to the management of these companies.  Many a time, many Singaporeans have given feedback to the Government, the latest being the recommendations by the ERC, where the recommendations are for the Government not to interfere and be involved in business.  While there was seemingly good reception by the

Government, the outcome does not show it has, and will let go.  While many of them are already listed companies, we continue to see a strong influence of the Government, including giving helping hands to some of these companies, hence creating an unlevel playing field in the perception of others and, I think, this is to the detriment of the private sector.  Of course, it took the USA, through its FTA, to pressure the Government to back off from playing a dominant role in the Government-owned companies, I feel that the Government could have reacted earlier, but I guess we have to thank the US FTA for this, that the level playing field may be created very soon.

 

     Sir, two examples which stand as cases where the Government is being directly involved in the affairs of the Government-owned companies are SIA and PSA.  In both cases, we see very senior Ministers getting directly involved, despite the fact that both of them supposedly have strong management teams and boards running them.  This is not a good signal and is not in line with what the Government has been saying about its role in managing its Government-owned companies through its investment arms. 

 

     Another example I can remember is the proposed merger of our transport companies.  In that case, again, the Government, through a Minister, jumped the gun to go public with his suggestion that the companies should merge into one entity.  Both companies are listed and it should have been their own decision.  Of course, the Government could advise these companies, but this could have been done, not publicly, I believe.  They could have a private discussion, rather than to come out in the open.  Sir, my point is that the signals that we are giving are not good, not just to private companies in Singapore but also to other countries, about the dominant role that the Government is playing.

     Similarly, I feel that the Government continues to have a dominant role in financing companies.  Currently, I feel that there is too much money in the hands of too few people, particularly held by the Government funds and Government economic agencies.  We all know that money talks and, therefore, by giving money to a few people to manage, we created a lopsided outcome as to how and where the money gets invested.  This is particularly so because of the type of people who are appointed to the agencies managing the money.  They mainly come from the same background, being Government-appointed.  I suggest that the Government change its approach by spreading the money around and by giving it to more agencies, both Government agencies as well as non-Government agencies.  I have seen a number of Government agencies which were so limited in funds that they are not able to do what they really want to do effectively,  whilst some other agencies have lots of money and, therefore, they continue to support one cross-section of industry that we should be supporting.  We could learn from the USA model where the Government deploys some of its funds to organisations like the Small Business Investment Corporations (SBICs), or we could deploy some of our funds to be managed by some successful Singapore businessmen for investment in private companies, whether start-ups or established companies.  I am sure that the overall return will be more interesting than what the Government has been able to derive from its current investment arms.  This would then go a long way in resolving the financing problems of our local entreprenuers and companies.

 

     Sir, in conclusion, having said the above, I would nonetheless thank the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance for giving his support to the entrepreneurship drive in Singapore by announcing the few initiatives in this year's Budget.  What is not so obvious is

Column: 587

that the Government has been very receptive to a series of recommendations made by private sector groups, and I have been involved in some of them.  We have recommended a number of initiatives which we hope would make Singapore a very vibrant place for entrepreneurship and for financing entrepreneurs and start-ups, and also for financing of local companies.  The Government has agreed to many of the recommendations.  And now, the action crucible for financing, which is subgrouped under ACE that I am heading, is working to implement as many of the recommendations as possible and I am glad to note that the Government is very receptive and I hope it continues to do so, because I believe if it can implement these things we will really have a change of landscape in Singapore.

 

     Sir, I had a wish-list which I presented during the 2002 Budget debate.  I still stand by those items but I do not want to spend time talking about them down here.  Most of those items were related to cost reductions and I hope that the Government could seriously get back on track and walk the talk in really addressing the cost issues in Singapore so that we could attract and retain long-term companies and investors into Singapore, thereby creating more jobs for our fellow Singaporeans.  The economy is recovering and optimism is in the air, but we all need to realise that while we would see good times again, sooner or later, we would again face tough times as the economic cycles shorten.  If we start resting on our laurels and fail to address these issues I highlighted, the next time it may be too late for us.  So I hope that the Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister would seriously look at the recommendations that I have made, particularly in the area of cost reduction.

 

     Sir, with that, I support the motion.

I recommend that the Government bear the following in mind when mapping the overall strategy:

with the Government's prescriptive approach. Column: 594

think there are other serious implications that will befall our society and which we will have to face.  For example, with fewer babies born each year, will there be enough Singaporeans to defend our country, notwithstanding our aggressive use of technology in the SAF?  And with fewer babies born each year, will there be enough skilled workers to attract investments and anchor jobs here?

     Sir, these are not idle questions for some distant generation to answer.  Many of us might still be around in 2020 or even 2030.  It is therefore in our own best interests that we begin to turn the tide now sooner rather than later.

 

More babies

 

     The most direct approach is, of course, to encourage Singaporeans to have more babies.  I say it is direct, but it is not simple.  From the feedback I got from union leaders, grassroots leaders and some of the ideas being talked about, such as longer maternity leave for mothers, higher subsidies for infant care and childcare, flexible family-friendly work arrangements, should all be helpful.  By enabling more time for the mother to bond with the child and by lowering the cost of care for the household, it will lower barriers to child-bearing and rearing.  So, the direction is the right one.

 

     The question is over cost-effectiveness and who should bear which part of the cost.  Clearly, employees

would want any additional maternity leave to be paid leave.  They would also like to see significant increases in infant care subsidies so that the net cash outlay on their part is roughly similar to the current net cash outlay for childcare and the gap can be substantially narrowed.

     From the perspective of Singaporean couples who have children, they would want to avail themselves fully of any new initiative.  From the Government's standpoint, initiatives should be targeted at encouraging increase over the "natural" outcome  -  net increases  -  rather than huge deadweight costs.  There is no simple solution.  If it were so simple, it would have been solved already.  And these are delicate balances to strike, and I can appreciate that.  If a workable compromise can be achieved, then we can, hopefully, stem the decline of our birth rate.  But at the same time, if the balance is struck wrongly, it could be a huge waste of money and it could have adverse effects on business and employment.  I therefore do not envy the job of the Minister in this regard.

 

     In considering the various measures, I do urge the Government to give priority to items

    

that are within its more direct control, such as infant care and childcare subsidies.  In the so many measures that are being talked about, not every one of them is easy to get a settlement on.  But those that we can make an earlier decision, I think we should.  And therefore in this way, there is no need to hold up all things just because some things cannot be resolved readily.

     At the same time, I urge employers to take a longer term view to these efforts.  To the extent that the efforts succeed, you would have better assurance of a larger pool of workers in the future.  Hence, you can look upon this exercise as one of investing in your company's own future labour supply, rather than just an immediate increase in cost.

Reducing infant mortality further?

    

     Sir, I also look at different ways in which we can increase the net supply of babies.  I look at the infant mortality rate.  In 1960, it was 34.8 per thousand births.  Over the decades, reflecting improved economic circumstances and healthcare, that has been greatly brought down.  According to MOH statistics, it is now below three per 1,000 births, and it is amongst the lowest in the world and it is on par with the most advanced countries.  So, infant mortality rate reduction will not yield us many more births in this regard.

 

Fewer abortions?

 

     But there is another area that we should examine, and that is abortion.  According to the Ministry of Health's Annual Report 2001, total abortions in Singapore totalled around 13,800 each year from 1997 to 2000.  I do not have the figures beyond the 2001 report.  But assuming that they have been around the same these past few years, then it is a large loss of  births in relation to total births of only 37,000 last year.  For every

three babies born, one other baby is aborted.

 

     Sir, I recognise that abortions are done for many different reasons, ranging from medical, social to economic.  But, perhaps, not every abortion is unavoidable.  By examining the factors behind the abortions in even greater detail than we have done so far, we might yet be able to bring down that number.  And if we can reduce these abortions by a third, or maybe even a fifth, it would make a significant difference.

 

More adoptions?

 

     And even as some Singaporeans abort their pregnancies, there are others who are not able to conceive and who would want to adopt children.

 

     According to a Sunday Times' article on 7th March, it says and I quote, "There is no ballpark figure of how many people are in the queue at adoption agencies.  But in the last four years, Singaporeans have adopted an average of 700 children a year.  In this regard, we can study how adoption processes can be adjusted or reconfigured to facilitate adoption and matching, especially amongst Singaporeans.

The sandwiched class

 

     Sir, as we home in on the measures directed at births, we must also recognise that couples make decisions about

childbearing, taking into account a wide variety of factors.  One of those factors is the pressure felt by the sandwiched class - people who have to support both their parents' generation and also their children.  This pressure has physical, financial and emotional dimensions.  It is accentuated by a low birth rate, because each succeeding generation has fewer working adults to support a larger number of elderly, while concurrently having to face the rising cost and stress of bringing up the next generation.

 

     Younger couples may therefore ask themselves whether there will be enough money, and enough people, to responsibly support such care to the generation before them and the generation after them.  In the overall calculations, there will be trade-offs.  Nuclear families make these questions even more pertinent because there is a loss of inter-generational bonding, mutual help and economies of scale that the larger family group can supply.  So there is a double whammy with growing needs for both childcare and eldercare.

 

     My point here is that we will have to further step up our actions with regard to enhancing the employability of older workers and addressing eldercare needs, as part of our total efforts to get better results at the birth end.  And by providing concrete ways forward on the issue of enhancing the employability of older workers, eldercare and fostering intergenerational bonding and mutual support, we will help lower the overall pressure on the middle generation, and that might further increase the chances of their having more children.

 

Top-up through immigration

 

     Sir, notwithstanding actions to increase and save births, I believe that it would still be a very uphill task to achieve replacement rate in the immediate future.

For this reason, I think it would be necessary for Government to consider additional ways to increase immigration.  Of course, we are not interested in just bringing in the numbers.  All along, the policy of the Government has been to be careful and selective about granting permanent residency and citizenship, allowing only for those who can and will add value to our society, and also being very clear that if you are not desirable, then we do not want you here.  I support such a prudent stance.  However, we should examine further to see if there are ways of integrating our processes more closely to induce more potentially eligible foreigners, such as those who study and work here, to take up permanent residency.  As Singapore's drive to becoming an education hub takes shape, there should be more opportunities for us to do this.  Australia, for example, is able to benefit by augmenting its talent pool through tapping on its large body of foreign students.

 

     The road from permanent residency to citizenship will certainly not be a straightforward one.  We should review holistically the slate of benefits accruing to citizens versus permanent residents, and ensure that there is a significant difference. This is to give a stronger incentive to eligible permanent residents to seek our citizenship at an earlier rather than later time.

 

Anchoring Singaporeans

 

      Just as we must try all means to minimise the attrition on births and induct valuable immigrants, we must continue to do our utmost to retain the hearts of Singaporeans in their country and its future, wherever they may work.  Indeed, the Prime Minister spent a good part of this National Day rally speech last year driving home this point.

      Being pragmatic, I think, is as in-born a Singaporean trait as you can find one.  So I believe that in the overall scheme of things, it ultimately boils down to how we make this place a land of opportunity where talent and effort unite to make hopes and dreams come true, and this is the very subject of this and previous Budgets.

 

Let us move ahead

 

     Sir, Singapore has overcome many obstacles in our journey from third world to the first.  At every turn of the road, we encountered new challenges and tough choices.  Each time, we tackled the problems head-on with sound logic, always planning ahead, placing the long-term interests of our people first and adapting with the times.  That was how we forged ahead and succeeded.  We must now move with equal resolve and speed to tackle the twin challenges of low birth rates and a rapidly aging population, and thereby secure a better future for Singaporeans.

 

      Sir, I support the motion.
