Column: 604

performance of the workers by tying it with their family lives, so that there will be a good work-life balance. 

 

     Now, let me look at the intangible measures.  Just now, I mentioned that, in fact, in the last few days, I have looked at the various incentive measures, and there are more than 50 of them.  In fact, the Government has already done a lot in tax reliefs, in public education in the schools, and creches.  The Government has made a lot of arrangements.  But there is still room for improvement for these arrangements, for example, in work arrangements.   In the past, as a trade unionist, I was quite sceptical about the five-day week idea.  Recently, after visiting some MNCs, such as IBM, AT&T and Shell,   I dropped   my reservations on   the five-day week.  Take Shell, for example. They function 365 days a year and 7 days a week.  But most of their workers work only a five-day week.  So, we should not hesitate in the move towards a five-day week arrangement. 

 

     We should have more flexibility, with the Government in the lead. Our quasi-Government departments and statutory boards should restructure themselves, so that we can adopt the five-day week.  Just now, I mentioned about this flexible work arrangement.  Now, we have the computer, fax, email and video conferencing.  We can use these new technologies to re-engineer our work. 

 

     Recently, I attended a conference where an American professor gave a talk.  Physically, he was in Japan, but we could raise questions with him and have real time discussion through  video conferencing.  In some countries, they even use the video to conduct lectures.  They do not have to be physically present in the lecture hall.  Now, we have people all rushing to work at the same time.  Why can we not arrange to have   flexible working hours and staggered time for our workers?  

 

Column: 605

     I think we should all sit down and feedback to Mr Lim Hng Kiang and his committee our suggestions as MPs, Mayors, employers, or Ministers.  Everyone should play a part.  For example, you say, if I want to start an enterprise, everyone should tell the Minister what they want to do, and not tell the Minister what to do.

 

     In a family, parents help their children to look after their children.  So, in a family, you can say, "Young people go ahead, have more children.  When I retire, I will help you to look after your children."  In our community, we should have more facilities, such as childcare centres and even baby-care centres.  Now the Government provides   subsidies for childcare centres.  But I think the facilities for the care of babies are still not enough.  I will raise this during our Committee of Supply on Health and MCDS.  But I think the Government has not given any subsidy for the cost of looking after babies at home.

 

     Another aspect is on education.  Personally, I am very proud of our education system.  Whenever I am overseas, when people ask me, "Which policy in Singapore are you most proud of?", I would reply that I am most proud of our education system in Singapore.  Because, in Singapore, every child, irrespective of family background, whether rich or poor,  has the chance to go to school and the opportunity to make full use of their potential.  Even then, I cannot say our education system is perfect.  We can still look at rooms for improvement. We want to cultivate our children into useful citizens. This is again a question of output.  Do we want to cultivate an engineer, a lawyer, a technician, a doctor or an all-rounded person?  We want to cultivate the children, so that they can make full use of the potential in every aspect, eg, in the arts, sports and even in hotel catering, in

Column: 606

business, science, law and leadership quality.  Everyone has different talents.

 

     I support the views expressed by the Acting Minister for Education in an interview by the Straits Times.  I think we should make every child give full play of their potential, so that they can have the opportunity to express themselves.  We can say that all parents in Singapore place great emphasis on the education of their children.  We should give priority to school enrolment for the third child.  I think this would be even more attractive than fiscal incentives.  Now, we have given more autonomy to the schools and universities to enrol the students, I think it is very good.  I think we should also give this autonomy to our junior colleges and secondary schools. If they want to go for one session, full-day school, and for schools to have childcare centres, we should help them.

 

     Every family's need is different.  When we want to take these measures, we should not think that, by giving a Baby Bonus, everything is resolved.  That is not good enough.  This time, we are suggesting extended maternity leave.   Will it solve everything?  It may be a good measure, but not a perfect solution.  It is not to say that everyone will take the six-month maternity leave.  Some would say we want to breast feed, so we may have to take six months' leave.  But some females may have siblings or parents to look after the baby, they may not need such a long maternity leave and they would prefer to convert this maternity leave to family leave so that they can take leave in a more flexible manner.  We should look at this maternity leave issue in a more flexible way.  Just now, I mentioned about this Baby Bonus. For this fiscal incentive, we give bonuses for the second and third children.  Some families do not even have the first child.  Although money is not the absolute factor to encourage child birth, I think this would, in some way, help to cut down on their

Column: 607

financial costs. I also feel that there are too many rules, eg, you must give birth within a certain period, etc.  So, if late birth is not an issue, why should we make it so complicated?  So long as you produce the birth certificate, whether you have a second or third child, I just give you the money, that is all.  Why all these terms and conditions?  Maybe we should not give them cash, lest they misuse it.  Maybe we could have a trust fund for medical fees, education fees, etc.

 

     Another issue is on marriage itself.   I think marriage itself is a problem.  If you do not get married, how do we have babies?  So, I think this is very important.  The MCDS has already started the Public Education Committee to promote this, through the schools, the religious bodies and the clan associations. Talking about   the clan associations,   recently, the Minister of State Mr Chan Soo Sen said that the clan associations seemed to have nothing much to do nowadays.  To this, I would say that there are a lot of things they could do. They can help to promote marriage and the bearing of children.  I hope that the clan associations will encourage the young people to get married, and get married early. 

 

     Perhaps, my suggestion will also have to take into consideration the fact that the boys have problems because of National Service, although I fully support National Service.  Some people say that the best time to start courting is when you finish your  'A' levels or polytechnic, and that it is the best time to start courting!  We should give them a "gap year" after the 'A' levels or the polytechnic, so that the young boys could catch up with the young girls to do some social, charitable or welfare work together.  This need not be confined only to Singapore.  They can even go to other countries, so that they can cultivate the relationship, to experience social contacts with the

Column: 608

opposite sex.   So, I feel that we could look into the possibility of providing for such a "gap year". Maybe the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Community Development and Sports could look into how to create more chances for the young people to socialise.

 

     We should have this motto: "We are behind you!"   Now, a lot of young people are worried.  They say, "You want us to have children, but we do not even have a steady job, what certainty can we have for our future?"    If we can say "We are behind you", not only the parents will say it, our friends and relatives should also say it.  Our siblings, if their children are grown up, we should also help our younger brothers and sisters to look after their children.  The employers should also say, eg, "All right, if you want to take leave, we can do this, we can do that, and we will support you."  And for those young people who are just married, we should show that we are behind them. Give them the assurance that help is available, as and when they need it. So, with this national effort, ie, the parents, siblings, families, Mayors, MPs, we can show the young couples that "We are behind you". Let us do it.

 

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): With your kind permission, Sir, I too would like to join in this Great Baby Debate.

 

     Sir, last year, I came across this very interesting report.  This is a 2003 global survey on sexual attitudes and behaviour conducted by Durex, a condom manufacturer, and it covered over 150,000 people in 34 countries.  The survey found that Singapore adults were the least amorous in the world.  For once, we did not turn out to be Number 1 in a survey.  Not only did our results rank last in the world for the number of times that our adults had sex in a year, we were also the only nation where the number fell below what the survey called the magic 100 mark - to be exact, only 96 times a

Column: 609

year.  Some of us may want to take the Durex report with a pinch of salt.  But it is one more way of looking at the problem of declining births.  If Singaporeans are, firstly, not inclined to be passionately romantic, how are we going to produce babies?

 

     Sir, amidst all this search for schemes to make sure that our young adults produce babies, I think we may have to start from the starting point.  I cannot be more colourful and more graphic, but how can we get them to be more romantic and to be more passionate about romance and, hopefully, then allow nature to take its course?  But, as they say, Singapore is not a very romantic place.  And how can you blame them?  If one were to take a walk past some of our office blocks at night, one might not be too surprised to see how many offices are still lighted up.  One will find young accountants auditing their books in order to meet quarterly reporting deadlines; lawyers scrambling to have agreements drawn up because their clients have to complete their deals by the morning; and bankers dealing with financial markets that are still open elsewhere because of differences in time zones.  So, small wonder that many couples, young or old, rarely find the time for one another, let alone think of having a child.  Most are too exhausted after a long day and night at work. 

 

     But this has been a society which urges everyone to work hard or you would not survive.  Strive for excellence, compete or perish.  This has been the Government's mantra for decades.  Nothing wrong with this, mind you, except that, faced with this kind of stress, parents do not want to have children who will also have to face the prospects of their own rat race in the future.  So, it does not take much logic to reason why many opt to have just one quality child who can take on the world when his or her time comes.  They can then focus all their resources on that one

Column: 610

child, and that includes paying for all types of private tuition needed to make sure that little junior scores straight A's in his examinations.  A Straits Times survey recently found that it costs $77,000 just to pay for a child's education from pre-primary to university level. 

 

     What can we do to make couples change their minds and have at least two children?  That is the burning question we have to deal with.  We tried financial and tax incentives but have found that they do not work.  And I am not so sure that rolling out more taxpayers' money is the only solution to our problem. 

 

     Neither is providing more paid maternity leave the panacea for our ills.  Much has been made of the reservations expressed about extended maternity leave, not just by employers but even by some women employees themselves.  And I do not wish to repeat them here.  But let me just add that extended paid maternity leave is a tried formula in many countries that has brought only mixed results.  In Italy, for example, a woman gets 20 weeks of paid maternity leave; in Austria, 16 weeks; Hungary, 24 weeks; Spain, 16 weeks; Japan and Germany, both have 14 weeks.  Yet, all these countries have Total Fertility Rates (TFRs) close to or below ours.  Yes, there are a few countries with long periods of paid maternity leave and higher TFRs.  But none has reached replacement fertility.  Interestingly enough, the United States and New Zealand are two countries with unpaid maternity leave: 12 weeks in the US, and 14 weeks in New Zealand, and the US has a TFR of 2.11 and New Zealand, 2.01, close to replacement rate. 

 

     Sir, there are women who feel that long maternity leave is in fact disruptive to their work and careers.  Paternity leave has been suggested too, but I think this is probably not a good solution.  If our male citizens have to do reservist training for up to 42 days in a year, any additional

Column: 611

days off from work would be highly disruptive to any organisation.  Many people, Sir, would prefer, say, half a day off or a day off mid-week to spend with their children, in other words, a move towards more flexible working arrangements.  Perhaps we might want to make a national move towards a 5-day working week, so that all of us can spend more quality time with our families. 

 

     Other policies can also be relooked.  A case in point is the foreign maid levy, a policy to contain the number of foreign maids working in Singapore.  Sir, with 140,000 maids in Singapore, each attracting a levy of $345 a month, it has actually become a very convenient cash cow for the Government to milk.  But then it is parents who suffer because, with the levy, a maid today can cost between $600 and $700 a month.  This is no small sum for a young couple.  Do they turn to parents for help in raising the child?  Not likely because, in many instances, some parents and in-laws would probably still be working.  But if we really want to ease the worries of young working couples who need someone to take care of their children when they are at work, then we must lighten the burden of hiring someone.  It is not the ideal solution, I agree, to have someone else, not least a foreigner, bring up one's child.  But the Government must examine its priority in this area: whether to continue with what is viewed by many as a revenue-raising measure, or whether it wants to achieve a larger social objective.  If it is to be the latter, then the Government must be prepared to bite the bullet on this and consider lowering the levy.

 

     Sir, while we are talking of foreigners, let me just add how painful it is, as an MP, for me sometimes to come across cases of Singaporeans who are denied permission to marry the person they love

Column: 612

because their desired spouse happens to be a work permit holder.  On the one hand, we lament the low rate of success of the Government's match-making agency, the Social Development Unit, but we readily deny those who find love on their own, just because one partner happens to carry a card that says, "You are here to work only, and you cannot marry a Singaporean."  Or what about the many Singaporeans who have foreign spouses, but we tell the foreign spouses that "Marriage to a Singaporean does not confer on you the automatic right to live in Singapore"?  Many such couples want to start families in Singapore, but our rigid immigration rules do not even allow them to live together.  Sir, if we want to make every baby count, we need to re-examine the rationale behind some of these rules and find ways to relax them.

 

     Sir, there is another area I am concerned about in the Budget Statement, and this is the intention of the Government to raise fees for university students.  While it may be a simple solution to suggest that students need not worry too much about the coming increase in fees as they can always pay later when they are working, the Government may be unwittingly adding to our procreation blues.  Can you imagine that we would end up having young people who will already be in debt the day they graduate?  Repaying their study loan will of course have to be their priority.  This means delaying their ability to marry early and start a home and their family, because there would be the mortgage to think of, and you do not want to think of another loan until you have got the first one off your back.  In fact, one would-be parent in his 30s put the problem to me in another way.  He said, "If I have a son and I look after him, I will have to look after him for actually a quarter of a century because, by the time he completes his NS and he graduates, he would be close to 25 years of age and I will be close to 60.  If I have a second

Column: 613

son a few years later, that would take me to over 60 years of age, and I shudder to think if I also have to help them pay their university loans.  And the Government is telling me that there is no such thing as life-long employment, and I am seeing many of my friends becoming unemployed in their mid-40s.  So, I think having one child is already dicey enough."

 

     Sir, there are many changes that we can make to encourage couples to have children and, no doubt, we will hear many more ideas in the next two days.  It is a serious problem we are faced with, and I find it disconcerting to read stories in the newspapers that seem to glorify those who do not want to have children.  Sir, last week, the Straits Times ran a series of articles over some days.  One story last week showed a couple looking very happy with the headline saying: "No rushing the stork".  Next to this was a picture of another couple with their child and it read:  "One is enough for now".  Then, a few days later - to be exact, last Saturday - there was another

story of a journalist smugly proclaiming that although she loved children - other people's children, that is - marriage and having babies were just no-no to her.  Another story the same day had another reporter who simply said that she could not stand bawling babies around her, forgetting that all of us at one time or another must have been pesky little kids to another generation of adults.  Not only that, she said that having babies would surely put paid to her plans for going on holidays and there was no way anything the Government could do to make her change her mind about having a child.

 

     Sir, I think such stories are not helpful to what we are trying to achieve.  I think what we need to have is more pro-family stories.  Let me say that as one who is a parent, there is nothing more fulfilling than having and bringing up your own children.  Both my wife and I have had to pursue our own careers but we have

Column: 614

shared the joys of parenthood.  In raising our children, we had been through their ups and downs with them and we had shared their trials and tribulations.  There have been times when they have made me angry but there had been many more moments when they have made me happy and proud.

 

     To those who still eschew the idea of  having children, let me ask them to look some 30 years into the future and ask themselves what kind of Singapore will we then have.  Would it not be a Singapore lacking the vibrancy that we now have?  Let me ask them who is going to look after them when they can no longer look after themselves?

 

     Sir, there is no one size solution to fit all in this issue. Mr Lim Hng Kiang and his Committee have an unenviable task to find the solutions, and they may not even find them all by National Day but he deserves our support.  The problem is such a perplexing one, and it is so crucial for our long-term survival, maybe even more so than Dr Ng Eng Hen, he needs to have his bonus pegged to how successful he can produce babies for us.  Sir, no pun intended, of course.

 

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): Mr Speaker, Sir,  I agree with the previous speakers that this is indeed an interesting Budget.  It deals not only with specific issues of concern to the economy but, of equal importance, it sets important outlines on issues of significance to us as a society.

 

     In terms of economic issues, the focus of this year's Budget is on enhancing Singapore's competitive edge. In this respect, this year's Budget continues with the process that was started last year to put in place some of the key recommendations of the ERC. Some Singaporeans have expressed disappointment though, that there are no goodies for the individuals, except for the

Column: 615

Medisave top-up for those above 50 years of age, whereas many incentives were given to companies. To the extent that this Budget will help to further strengthen companies and attract more investments, I hope that there will be a trickle down effect, and ultimately all Singaporeans will benefit. 

 

     Let me now make specific comments on some aspects of this Budget.

   

    On the issue of halting the falling birth rate, I agree with DPM that a comprehensive approach is needed. To me the issues that we are confronted with can be categorised into three areas: cost, time and supporting infrastructure. In NTUC, our Women's Committee had conducted dialogue sessions with a few hundred women leaders and activists. The feedback that came across loud and clear is that cost is still a major factor affecting a couple's decision on whether or not to have children and, if so, how many.  In this connection, many had said that they were not looking at just the cost at the time of the birth of a child, but to them, it is a whole process from infancy to adulthood. On the issue of time, many women also pointed out that there were insufficient alternative work arrangements, such as part-time work or teleworking, to widen their choices after childbirth. Currently, their only choices are to stay at home to look after the children or to remain in the workforce. Additionally, many also felt that there is a need for a more supportive environment at the workplace for working parents. In this connection, of course, we have been working very closely with the MCDS in order to promote work-life balance at the workplace, and we are happy to say that there are some positive results but more could be done.  In Japan, for instance, there is a good percentage of women doing telework.  In the Scandinavian countries where there is a high female

Column: 616

labour force participation rate, there are many flexible work arrangements for working mothers.

 

     Sir, the proposal to lengthen their maternity leave, despite many misgivings, is an important one to me as it will also partly overcome the problem of lack of affordable infant care facilities. But the issue of discrimination against women will have to be dealt with, as many women are concerned about how the improved benefits will affect them in the job market. The point to note here is that in most of the countries where there are generous benefits for women to take care of the family, there is also legislation to protect their right to keep their jobs after they return to work and to provide a system for women who are discriminated against to file a complaint. It will be interesting to see whether without such a supporting legislation the measures that are put in place here will be effective to prevent discrimination against women. In this context, I would like to suggest that even if the Government is not prepared to consider legislation at this point of time, nevertheless, it needs to put a mechanism in place to monitor the impact of such policies, otherwise the market will take care of itself. Women will not avail themselves of the longer maternity leave and have more babies because they fear they may lose their jobs. As one employer had put it in a newspaper interview recently, if it was just too troublesome he would not employ women.

 

     The other way of ensuring that there will be no discrimination against women if they avail themselves of the longer maternity leave is to extend this benefit to fathers as well.  I am not saying that fathers will now start conceiving but what I am saying is that we could describe this additional period of leave as parental care leave which can be enjoyed by either the father or the mother.  In this way, the disruption to the workplace and cost to the employer will be spread out.  At the

Column: 617

same time, we also encourage fathers to assume greater responsibility over child-rearing and family responsibilities.  Over time, this will by itself create a momentum, in terms of changing of society's norms and perceptions about work and family. 

   

    Sir, I would also like to add that we should not view this issue of procreation from a narrow, temporary perspective of how many babies will be born to support our economic growth or contribute to our GDP. If we cast this entire debate and put all our efforts to boost the birth rate solely from a purely economic angle, we may see some results in the short term, but I doubt that it will be truly sustainable in the long term. Economics and society are inextricably bound and intertwined. The policies that we adopt do shape our society. They are a reflection of our values, and they send important messages to our youths about what we value. A society that values children, parenthood and the family is far different from a society that does not.

 

     The ongoing debate that we are having today is healthy as it enables more people to buy into the idea. Through this process, we can then develop a consensus on the kind of society that we want and what we are prepared as Singaporeans - the Government, employers, workers and everyone who has a stake here - to put in place to support these values.

   

    Sir, how to address Singapore's declining fertility rate is not an easy issue.  It is a complex and intricate issue involving many facets.  The current approach however has serious limitations as they are ad-hoc and it is not multi-agency except when a problem crops up and a committee is set up to deal with the issue as we are now doing.  I would like to suggest therefore that the Government seriously consider setting up a multi-agency body that will champion issues

Column: 618

concerning the family and would also act as a sounding board for all policies or programmes that will impact on the family.

 

     Sir, let me now come to the other points in the Budget.

 

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister has given us an overall assessment of the economy. Singapore continues to remain as a competitive manufacturing location especially for high-tech, high value-added activities. However, in the same breath, we are also told that the manufacturing sector is not likely to generate many more jobs as MNCs are shifting to higher value-added, less labour-intensive activities, and will increase output per worker rather than hire more workers. Hence, to create more jobs for Singaporeans, there will be strong emphasis on the services sector. But looking at the trend that is taking place today, there is cause for concern. Many companies are outsourcing their services. In the past, only blue collar, manufacturing jobs are outsourced but today outsourcing involves white collar and higher value-added jobs as well. Even the Government is outsourcing, a trend which the Finance Minister has stressed will continue and in fact even intensified through the Best Sourcing Directive of the Ministry of Finance.


     In this light, my question is where are the jobs coming from? Will the number of jobs that are created be enough to cover the number of school leavers entering the job market and soak up those who are retrenched or unemployed? What more can be done to encourage companies that are based here to try and retain the jobs in Singapore, and even if they have to outsource, to do so to local companies? Has there been an assessment of the impact of outsourcing on our economy and jobs and with the growth of India and China, what will be the future implications? Will outsourcing intensify

Column: 619

and, if so, which are the more vulnerable sectors?  I think it is important that we address these questions as the concern down the ground continues to be whether enough jobs will be created - a concern which is further compounded by the announcement that we will be making permanent residents here much more attractive in order to attract more foreigners to sink their roots here.

 

     Sir, I can also see a certain contradiction in our policies.  On the one hand, the focus is on creating more higher value-added jobs for Singaporeans. But at the same time, the policies affecting the employment of foreign workers are made more liberal. I am referring specifically to the new category of "S" passes that are being created to replace the Q2 passes. Unlike the R passes for skilled and semi-skilled workers, and the P passes for professional workers, the "S" passes are meant to attract the middle-tier skilled workers with diploma and post-secondary level education. The feedback I have received is that Singaporeans fear that the "S" pass workers will pose a direct competition to our polytechnic and university graduates. It is not competition per se that Singaporeans are concerned about.  Rather, their concern is that they may pose an unfair competition with Singaporeans because they can be employed at much lower cost than Singaporeans, as their minimum salary is only $1,800. There is also no restriction on their countries of origin compared to the previous Q2 passes that are now being abolished. This concern has some basis as last year's retrenchment figures show that a higher proportion of those retrenched are executives. With the presence of the "S" passes, this will be the category that will find it even more difficult to get employment if they are retrenched. I note in particular that the "S" passes will now be open to the healthcare, IT, aerospace and

Column: 620

pharmaceutical sectors.  These are high value-added industries and, if Singaporeans have to compete with foreigners even in these job sectors, I wonder how that would impact on the employment prospects of diploma holders and university graduates.

 

     I remember reading last week's report in the Straits Times that one in five polytechnic graduates ends up in a part-time job. I would therefore like to ask the DPM and Finance Minister, if he could kindly give an assurance that Singaporeans will not be displaced by foreigners and that our policies will continue to give priority to Singaporeans for good, high value-added jobs, now that the gates have been opened even wider. Although there is a limit of 5% imposed on the number of  "S" passes, based on past precedents, we know that it will only be a matter of time before employers agitate for an increase.

     I am particularly curious, Sir, why we have a shortage of such manpower that is now the target of the "S" passes, considering that we now have 5 polytechnics and two universities and we aim for a 60% rate in terms of the cohort entering university by 2010.  Does this indicate that our planning and manpower projections are not as effective as it should be in meeting the needs of the various sectors of the economy?  What more can be done to systematically identify areas or sectors in the economy where jobs are being created and to prepare Singaporeans for these jobs so that we will not have a situation where even higher value-added jobs end up with foreign workers?

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I strongly support the decision to raise the Skills Development Levy's salary ceiling from $1,500 to $1,800 in line with the increase in the number of training places that is projected from now onwards. Training and skills upgrading is of critical importance to our

Column: 621

workers to enable them to remain employable and this increase is, in fact, long overdue. However, there are limitations to the current system.  Workers continue to complain that employers are not prepared to train them for skills that are not relevant to their current job.  Workers, on the other hand, are concerned that if they stick only to job-related training, they may not be prepared for other jobs when they are retrenched. Workers are prepared to go for training at their own time even, but do need assistance in funding.

 

     In this regard, I would, therefore, like to urge the Government to consider some means of assisting workers who wish to attend non-job related training but which will prepare them for other sectors of the economy. We have mooted the idea of individual learning accounts on several occasions but somehow this has not received much support.  I would, therefore, like to ask for Government support again for this idea of an individual learning account for workers, in line with our focus to develop lifelong learning.  The Government can consider opening an account for every working adult with a CPF account and regularly topping this account much in the same manner that it has done in topping up the Medisave account for those above 50. In my view, this will go a long way towards promoting lifelong learning and employability.  It also sends a strong signal of Government's support for individual efforts at improving themselves.

 

     Let me now come to the next point, Sir.  This year, there will be a 2% cut in the budget for all the Ministries except MINDEF, and this will apply for FY 2004 and FY 2005.  Sir, I understand the rationale - revenues have become increasingly constrained because of the growth volatility and the reduction in corporate tax and other incentives given to companies have also affected the

Column: 622

revenue stream.  Nevertheless, my concern is whether this would have an impact on the Government's social expenditure.  Will this have an impact on the social assistance programmes run by the Ministries for the poor and needy and will these affect subsidies for services such as health and education?  I understand the need to balance the budget and to reduce deficits, nevertheless, my concern is how this will impact on help for low income families as there are still many who need help.  Although the retrenchment rate is expected to be lower this year, the rate of unemployment is still high and many Singaporeans continue to need help to secure jobs.  And, even those who are working will require support since their salaries may not be sufficient to meet basic needs.

 

     Next, Sir, I come to the point on Best Sourcing.  This requires public sector agencies to undertake "market testing", so as to compare the cost of providing their services in-house against the cost of having private sector vendors provide the services.  If private sector vendors can deliver the service more economically, they will be engaged to do so.  The public sector will then discontinue doing the function.  The public sector agency will then discontinue the function, and either redeploy or release the affected staff.  

 

     Sir, the rationale for Best Sourcing is understandable, nevertheless, in view of the current economic climate and the still high unemployment rate, there are concerns among public sector employees.  The older public sector employees feel particularly vulnerable.  Many fear that they will not get jobs so easily if they were retrenched as a result of Best Sourcing, particularly since employers today are still biased against older workers.  Many have also asked whether there is a need for the Government to also behave like the private sector, particularly

Column: 623

when the job market is still soft.  Some were also concerned that when jobs were outsourced these may invariably end up in the hands of foreign workers.     Sir, I see expenditure in education as an important and necessary investment in our people. I am, therefore, concerned that if the universities are allowed to set their own fees, university education may become too expensive and out of reach of low and middle income Singaporeans.  True, we should get students to pay a higher proportion of the fees but we should not kill the Singapore dream where everyone aspires for a better life through education.  Although there may be loan schemes available, I wonder whether it is really good to have so many young Singaporeans, like Mr Tan Soo Khoon said before me, burdened by a high level of indebtedness when they leave the university.  Again, like Mr Tan, I also wonder how this would affect their decision to get married, buy a house and have children.

 

     Hence, I would like to urge that we continue to ensure that university fees remain affordable to Singaporeans.  I do not see university education as benefiting the individual more, compared to investments in primary or secondary education.  We are a small country, Sir, and people are our only asset, coupled with the fact that many of the investments that we are bringing in are high value-added ones, there is certainly a need for more people with university qualifications.  It was not so long ago that Mr Philip Yeo who said that in the life sciences sector, those who have the first degree are only fit to wash test-tubes.  Hence, I would like to urge the Government to ensure that university education will continue to remain affordable and within the reach of the average Singaporean family.

 

    Sir, on means testing for hospital care, I agree with the principle that we need to focus subsidies on those who need them, and so make the most of our healthcare budget.  However, usually the devil lies in the details, and I would like to urge that before we introduce any means testing for

Column: 625

hospital care, we should study the issue very carefully.  I know that means testing has already been applied for step-down care and in a few other services, but hospital care is a different kettle of fish, as the cost involved is much more and, for those suffering from catastrophic illnessess, the medical bills are huge.

 

    Singaporeans who are really poor, and the upper income, will have fewer problems, but those caught in-between may face difficulties.  Likewise, those who suffer from a prolonged illness, even though they may be enjoying a certain income level, will have their savings wiped out and little monthly income to support their medical needs.  We also have to bear in mind that we are an ageing society, and we now want families to have more children.  If, as a result of the new means testing policy, they have to pay more in terms of hospital care, then our efforts at promoting procreation may be affected if families feel that they have to incur increased liabilities in meeting the healthcare needs of their children. 

   

    Many Singaporeans today are saddled with multiple responsibilities.  In addition to taking care of their own children, many have the responsibility of taking care of old and sickly parents.  If we use income alone as a yardstick, it may not be very helpful, as a person may be earning a certain income but it may not be sufficient for him to take care of his multiple needs.  Policy-making, Sir, is not an easy process and there are risks associated with any policy.  We do not want to see a situation where, because of certain policies, people do not seek treatment or they neglect their aged parents.  I do urge the Government to study these issues very carefully before proceeding with means testing, as healthcare is an issue which is close to the hearts of many Singaporeans.  Means testing should not be the only way in which we control healthcare cost in Singapore.  A lot more has to be done to

Column: 626

ensure that healthcare remains affordable, particularly, continuous efforts like identifying and addressing the areas which had caused the cost of hospital care to balloon over the years.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): Sir, I rise to support the Budget.

   

     The measures as proposed will continue to position Singapore as a land of opportunity for businesses, as well as for enterprising individuals.  The proposed 2% budget cuts for most Ministries will steer effective government, with expenses closely in check.  I am confident that with the structural adjustment in place in our tax system for businesses, thereby enhancing our competitiveness, we will be able to take advantage of the positive change in the economic environment, raise our sails once again and capitalise on another rising tide in the global economy in the coming years. 

 

     Notwithstanding this cautious optimism, however, one has to be realistic.  The global economy and indeed the geo-political landscape have changed in complexity significantly in the last decade.  Economic business cycles have become much shorter.  Shocks have become more periodic, and even endemic, as in the case of terrorism.  Global competition is especially keen with the emerging economies of India and China, a great opportunity for the nimble, but a threat for economies which rest on their laurels.

 

     Just as the private sector has had to adjust to the new economic realities, to be nimble, flexible and cost-efficient,  it is imperative that our public sector also responds in kind so as not to crowd out private initiatives.  I, therefore, applaud the DPM and Finance Minister for further cutting the size of the public sector.

 

     Sir, I noted, and more so as Chairman of the Estimates Committee in this House,

Column: 627

that reducing the size of the public sector has been a deliberate policy of the Government over the past years, and rightly so.  However, it is clear that this long-term task is even more relevant in an era where Government revenues have been increasingly constrained by shorter business cycles and volatile growth since the financial crisis in 1997, in contrast to the robust high growth era between 1987 and 1996.  Indeed, according to the Institute of Policy Studies, the cost of government, as measured by the ratio of operating expenditure to the GDP, has hovered around 10% since the 1990s, down from 15% in the 1980s, while tax revenue looks set to dip below 8% in this decade.  Government social expenditure, which accounts for close to 44% of the budget, is likely to impose further burden on the economy.  This is because of our ageing population trends, and especially in terms of healthcare and old-age related welfare costs.  Our increasingly vocal electorate also has a tendency to demand rebates and subsidies as a right from time to time. 

   

     Whilst we have consistently taken the rational practical approach, one has to recognise that in addressing some of these demands from time to time, a further stress on Government's coffers can be expected.  Singaporeans have to recognise that there is no free lunch all the time.  We cannot continue to expect more handouts and tax reliefs over time if we are seeing a falling revenue trend and if there are no corresponding cuts in Government expenditure.  Ultimately, Sir, the cost of running an over-sized government has to be funded from higher taxes, public debts, further privatisation of Government assets or dipping into accumulated reserves.

 

     Sir, whilst the Government has been proactive by proposing another budgetary

Column: 628

deficit of $0.7 billion in this year's Budget, I believe the principle of achieving a budget surplus over a business cycle must be maintained.

I believe this is a right-thinking philosophy that will enable Singapore to steer clear of structural budget deficits in the long run.  We must guard against increasing demands from all sectors of society for handouts and wean Singaporeans away from a dependency mindset.

 

     In line with this philosophy, I would like to urge the Government to continue with the implementation of means testing, not just in healthcare but also move away from across-the-board distribution of social handouts.  Instead, we should have a more coordinated approach in delivering social assistance schemes, so that distribution will  reach only those that really are in need of them.

   

     I note, for example, that the revenue impact of GST, raised in stages from 3% to 5% over the years, has been more than offset by handouts in the form of rebates and subsidies.  However, Singaporeans, some genuinely burdened by difficult economic conditions and others who are happy to free ride along, are both beneficiaries of mass distribution.  Indeed, some have even considered that it is a right entitled to them.  Sir, this perception that rebates and subsidies are rights that can be given in perpetuity has to be corrected, or it will add an ever increasing strain on our fiscal drawers. 

 

     Correspondingly, I support the various initiatives that have been taken by Government, directly and indirectly, to support education for consumers and citizens from personal financial responsibilities and discipline.  As a longer-term measure, perhaps the Education Ministry should also consider how such concepts, including public fiscal prudence, can be inculcated among our young in schools.

     Sir, on the overall Budget, the 2% budgetary cut across-the-board for all Ministries except MINDEF, in my mind, is a step in the right direction.  The cut does serve as a wake-up call to all Government Ministries.  It is no longer business as usual.  However, I would like to ask if it does go far enough.

   

     The current budgets in individual Ministries have evolved over the years, in many cases, in response to ad-hoc policies for social expenditure of specific needs in the Ministry, implemented as a right policy at that time but not necessarily the most relevant now, or necessarily well-targeted or coordinated with other Ministries and schemes.

 

     The Ministry of Finance, in allocating the budget, looks at the previous year's annual expenditure numbers and sets a target for growth or contraction of the Ministry's budget on an overall basis, leaving individual Ministries to allocate within, by and large.  Hence, with a 2% cut to be implemented, we could end up micro-managing Ministries.

 

     Ministries could end up focusing on cutting stationery, staff amenities and benefits and other perceived easy to tackle "wastes".  This is likely to lead ultimately to a reduction in civil servants' morale, whilst allowing for the potential perpetuation of out-dated schemes and programmes, or indeed processes which are inefficient or obsolete.

   

     Sir, one also hears of anecdotes where some Ministries, close to the end of the fiscal year, should they be under-budget, go to great lengths to "spend" the balance, so that they will not have their budgets cut the following year.  This is a real waste in itself and needs to be avoided.

 

     For the next FY 2005/06 Budget, I am therefore proposing that the Government conduct a zero based budget review

Column: 630

across-the-board for all Ministries.  The review should include a revisit of the mission, objectives, programmes and resource needs of all Ministries.  The result should enable a streamlining of Government activities, including subsidies, social assistance programmes and schemes.  It should also enable greater efficiency all round, if there is duplication across the Ministries for shared services.  If there are indeed expenditures for programmes no longer required, they should be terminated, thus incurring further cost savings.

   

     Sir, I believe the last time the MOF did a zero based budgeting exercise was many years ago.  A zero based budget review exercise conducted this year and subsequently once every five years will serve to ensure that the public sector remains vigilant, efficient and relevant, and delivers targeted services in tune with the times.  Who knows, the review might end up with a cut greater than the proposed 2% cut for the next fiscal year.

   

     On a related matter, I would also like to propose that the Government also review its annual grants to statutory boards with a fine tooth-comb.  The grant should be tied to a set of performance criteria and the level of accumulated surpluses, particularly where there is no more strategic use for the surplus.

 

     Sir, I recognise that the trimming of the Ministries' budget and a close check on Government expenses, if not properly managed, may create a morale problem among civil servants.  Indeed, I believe that it is already happening, based on initial feedback I have gathered from my constituents and grassroots leaders.  I want to ask whether the Government is ready to face this challenge and whether its personnel policies are geared to address this concern.

   

     In conclusion, Sir, in crafting Singapore's long-term competitive

Column: 631

position, our public sector's size and role is significant.  To be successful, we have to stay focused and be more efficient in delivering our public services, whilst realigning the expectations of future generations.  We should not overlook inefficiencies in our public sector and continue to lay the platform for greater flexibility whilst maintaining fiscal prudence in the face of keener economic competition globally.  Only in this way can we continue to ensure effective government in a land of opportunity for all.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang) (In Mandarin) :  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Lianhe  Zaobao described this year's Budget as a "Budget Focused on Long-term Goals."  Yes, we should look at what the Government's long-term goals are, examine their impact on our ordinary citizens and the implication on what lies ahead in the future.

 

      As before, this Budget was delivered in flowery language with barrels of reasons and principles, but with no regard for the people's livelihood.  And yet, concealed behind the vague and flowery language are many sparkling spectres.   Let us examine what are the financial policies and fundamentals that are laid down by DPM Lee.

 

     Firstly, DPM Lee said that in order to build an efficient government, he would cut by 2% the budget caps of all Ministries, except MINDEF, for this financial year, in order to reduce revenue shortfall and  to attain a balanced budget in FY 2005.  On the surface, reducing the Ministries' budgets and maintaining high efficiency appear to be reasonable.  But, what would be the reaction of the various Government departments when their budgets are slashed?

     To start with, the Ministry of National Development has already informed all the town councils that they would no longer support any HDB flat maintenance items which require heavy expenditure.  This implies that the cost for town councils will be significantly increased.  When the town councils can no longer afford such increases and start to run into deficit, would they not resort to raising the conservancy charges?  Once the conservancy charges are increased, then the meagre rebates granted by the Government over the years will be wiped off.

 

     The falling of one leaf heralds autumn.  With this, who can guarantee that the other Government Ministries will not increase their charges in order to compensate for this cut in the budget allocation?  Will the 2% cut be a catalyst for Government's productivity to go up?  Or will it directly result in the Government departments turning to the ordinary citizens and increase their charges to bridge the gap?  Will this also spark another round of business cost increase, resulting in our competitiveness being eroded?  Let us wait and see.

Column: 633

make up for this loss?  Can the Government explain why the NII on investments was 33% short of the original forecast?

 

     Secondly, DPM Lee said that we should encourage our people to be self-reliant, to be responsible for their own living and to build up a strong society.  To achieve this long-term goal, the fundamental of Government's fiscal policy is reducing the subsidy on university education and adopting means test to decide the amount of health care subsidy to each individual.  The Government said that maintaining the current ratio of subsidy on tertiary education will result in a squeeze on the resources for the primary and secondary schools.  It argued that university education will only benefit individual in securing employment and earn a higher income, whereas the secondary and primary education is more beneficial to the society as a whole.  Therefore, the current formula in university subsidy should be reviewed.  The reason of social benefit sounds grand, but behind it, it is simply the Government's unwillingness to continue to undertake the current subsidy of university fees for our people.

 

     When defending its foreign talent policy, the Government says that foreign talents play a key role in our economic development.  With them, we are able to strengthen our competitiveness to attract foreign investments, thus creating more job opportunities for our people.  The Government has actually spent a lot of money and resources to attract foreign students.  The Government, including statutory boards, spend public fund by providing them with tuition grants, bursaries and scholarships to study in our universities.  The increase of foreign students in our universities has also brought about higher cost to the manpower, facilities and financial resources in our universities.  Now when we need more taxpayers' money in

Column: 634

developing our own talents, the Government turns around and says that university education only benefits individuals in securing better employability upon graduation and, as such, they should pay more fees.  Could DPM Lee enlighten us what kind of logic is this?

 

     Is the Government saying that only foreign talents can bring benefits to our society and hence it is worth the while spending on them?   For our own students, university education only benefit them as individuals, therefore they have to be laden with debts the moment they graduate and start paying back with an expected lowered starting salary.  Is the Government saying that in our new knowledge-based economy, the role of our university graduates is only to secure higher salary for themselves?  The Government's message is simple, that is,  our local talent is not good enough.  We need foreign talents.  So, we could only cultivate foreign talents.  As for our own people, if they want to be recognised as talent, either parents have to foot the bill or they will end up with a heavy debt after graduating from university.

 

     DPM Lee also said that our social safety net must be carefully targeted and must not undermine our will to work and improve ourselves.  As such, subsidies should be focused on those who need them most and in areas which yield the most public good.  Means testing will, therefore, become an important feature in providing public services and social assistance.

 

      Mr Speaker, Sir, there is nothing wrong to encourage our people to be self-reliant and to make optimal use of our resources.  But what is the Government's responsibility to the people?  Should means testing be used as a norm to decide payment of basic public service is debatable.  When the Government says that subsidies should focus on those who need them most, any person who has

Column: 635

social justice at heart will generally accept this broad principle.  However, judging from the PAP Government's governing style, I am afraid this is going to be another trick with the real motive concealed.    The question is, who are those that most needed such subsidies? Are you saying that only those families whose income is less than $1,000 should be our focus, and those with $1,001 will not require the same level of assistance?  No doubt, we do need to help the lower income people, but what about those who are unemployed and those whose assets have devalued and the "new poor" in the middle class who are squeezed?  Do they not need the help too?  Will the use of means testing to decide the medical subsidy not result in higher medical costs for most of the patients?   If this is the case and the margin of increase is higher than the actual subsidies given to the needy, is the Government not benefiting from means testing?  If this is in need either in short term or in long term, would it not extend the norm of means test to other public services such as education?  Under the disguise of a broader objective of re-distributing public resources and building of a strong society, the middle-income group will be the ones who are squeezed most.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, what I would like to put to you is the fact that, regardless of whether the economy is good or bad, the burden of cost of living of our people in Singapore has never lessened, it has increased.  When the times are good, the Government will say, "Well, you can now afford it, so all the fees and charges will be increased!"   When the economy is bad, the Government will sit by and watch, and only step in when the people are in a state of extreme hardship.  Even then, the support they give to the people is hardly sufficient in helping them to tide over the difficult times, and the Government even rubs salt into the people's wounds by

Column: 636

emphasising how important it is to import foreign talents.   Now our economy has yet to be fully recovered, but the Government is already in such a hurry to withdraw the various rebates and to plan for a new fiscal landscape.  This budget has laid down the foundation of collecting more fees from the people by introducing means test in healthcare service and reviewing university subsidies in the name of building an efficient government and a strong society.

 

     DPM Lee in closing his Budget speech said, "Together, as one Singapore, we will build a future of opportunity for ourselves and our children."  However, if the Government is to adopt such financial principles and fundamentals I described above, then the future of ourselves and our children will be one that is full of stress and heavily laden with the burden of life.  They will be weighed down with the high cost of living and constantly struggling to live a life.  Under such circumstances, how many people will have the courage to have more children?

     Mr Ong Kian Min (Tampines): I support the Budget Statement of the Government.  It is a budget of prudent spending that nevertheless offers us a bold vision of reinforcing Singapore's position as a vibrant hub for businesses and talents to come and seek their opportunities.

Building a strong society

Singapore and what we stand for, that is, our national policies.  Travellers to Australia and New Zealand will tell you that these two countries are very particular in controlling the importation of foodstuff and organic matter.  Golfers will know that, on arrival, their golf shoes must be clean without traces of organic matter, plant or soil matter.  And, the authorities can be very pedantic about this.

     What do we Singaporeans say when we are called upon to defend our policies?  Take the world-renowned Singaporean ban on chewing gum.  Many Singaporeans, when asked by foreigners about this policy, cringe in embarrassment.  Do they see these policies as being imposed by the Government or do they see them as being for the common good?  Ask my daughter about her experience.  Recently,

Column: 643

we came back by coach from a church camp in Malaysia.  On the way back, she bought some confectioneries and these were in a thin transparent pink-coloured plastic bag.  When this bag of her goodies went through our Customs or security checks at Tuas, the officer noticed the contents of the bag and unilaterally, without notifying her confiscated two tubes of Hi-Chew.  Now, if you do not know, let me tell you that Hi-Chew is not chewing gum.  It is actually a chewy pastille that dissolves totally in your mouth.  My daughter was totally upset.  First, the  officer was poor in his product knowledge and, second, he was high-handed in confiscating the Hi-Chew without informing her.  You can imagine what she will say the next time someone brings up the subject of our chewing gum ban.  In the meantime, I am working on her.

 

     How can we motivate our people to believe wholeheartedly and passionately in what we stand for?  Singaporeans are law-abiding in nature and will obey new policies that are set.  However, convincing them of the reasons behind each policy is a challenge that each Government department must be mindful of.  It will require education, careful listening and addressing of feedback via multiple channels, much patience and relentless perseverance, and sensitive enforcement to convince them that the policies are not without meaning nor purpose.

 

Vibrant society - Danger of being regarded as a mediocre city

 

     Last week, I flew to Beijing and back.  On arrival at Beijing Airport, I was one of the first few coming off the plane and saw a row of five Chinese girls waiting to receive their foreign guests.  This is the airport's visitor receiving service; nothing

Column: 644

special.  They were elegantly dressed, in dark green cheongsam with gold embroidery, with their hair tied back.  Each of them held a small placard with the name of the visitor being received neatly printed on the placard.  A Caucasian man in front of me indicated he was one of those being received.  The girl stepped forward and in polished English said, "Welcome to Beijing, Mr Hopkins."  On my return to Singapore, when I arrived at Changi Airport, I would not say anything more.  You should take a look for yourself.  Her business jacket was a size or two too big and the visitor's name was scribbled with a marker pen on the whiteboard placard.

 

     Fortunately, the vibrancy of our city is not judged by this alone.  But a common complaint by Singaporeans is that there is little to do in terms of leisure in Singapore.  One Friday morning, I was listening to FM98.7 in the car while sending my children to school.  Daniel Ong, the DJ, asked one male listener, "What are you going to do this weekend?"  The listener replied, "Catch a movie."  Daniel Ong then remarked, "How come every time I ask my listeners what they are going to do, they say catch a movie?  Is there anything else to do?"  After a pause, the listener replied sheepishly, "No.  There isn't anything else to do."  Daniel Ong replied, "Ya, there isn't anything else better to do in Singapore."

 

     Sir, is Singapore as bland as some make it out to be?  This cannot be true.  One only has to visit East Coast Parkway during the weekends.  There, cyclists, young and old, are breezing up and down the cycling pathways which are full of roller-bladers whizzing past, watched in fascination by families who have set up tents of all sizes and all degrees of sophistication.  A quick informal survey has revealed activities as diverse as radio-controlled model aeroplane flying, fishing, sailing, football and tae-kwondo.

 

Column: 645

     What about leisure activities for those who prefer to stay indoors?  Besides our state-of-the-art movie theatres for movie-goers, there are people who indulge in all kinds of sports, cooking, bowling, dancing, karaoke, folk art, pottery, just to name a few.  At the Esplanade, we may be treated to art exhibitions, concerts, dance performances and theatrical events.  How come there are still Singaporeans who have nothing else better to do during the weekends, than to catch a movie?  And, who laments that there is much to do in other countries?  Perhaps, it is just that the grass on the other side of the fence is greener, or perhaps there is not enough information and publicity, giving Singaporeans ideas on how to have fun and enjoy life, or perhaps we are just plain lazy and just want to crash out and do nothing.  We should wipe out our dowdy image of a nation and a people obsessed with only economic success.  The goal should be for every Singaporean to work hard, work smart, play hard and have fun.  As the Nobel Prize winner in Literature in 1911, Mr Maurice Maeterlinck said, "Tell me how a people uses its leisure and I will tell you the quality of its civilisation."

 

Self-reliant society

 

     Next, on self-reliant society.  As we continue to develop into a modern vibrant society, we should move away from relying on the authorities to handle everything.  One example can be found in our neighbourhood environment.  As our HDB residents live in close proximity to each other, there will inevitably be minor disputes between neighbours over such day-to-day matters as dripping mops, curry being thrown out of the window, noise irritation and things cluttering up the common corridors.  Such cases are on the rise and residents look to the relevant authority, the town council or HDB, for redress and enforcement of regulations.  This situation is far from satisfactory.  Instead of having to seek the intervention of the town council or HDB every time a

Column: 646

dispute arises, we should allow more autonomy and self-determination at the local level.

 

     In order to foster a sense of belonging to the community and to encourage autonomy, the residents should be given some authority to make rules on local issues by majority decision, such as whether to censure the particular resident for behaving unreasonably.  In the US, the management committee of the apartment building can stipulate, for example, whether babies or young children should be discouraged in the building or they can prohibit flushing of toilets in the middle of the night.

 

Prudent spending - Living within our means

 

     Sir, next, I would like to touch on the second group of issues centering on prudent spending.  On living within our means and HDB upgrading programmes, the HDB upgrading programme was launched during the years of plenty when we enjoyed strong growth, rising property prices and budget surpluses.  Now, we have to tighten our belts and cut back on non-productive expenditure, and sensibly so.  We have to live within our means.  In every housing estate, you will find some precincts that were fortunate to be selected at that time and did in fact undergo upgrading, be it main upgrading, interim upgrading or lift upgrading.  By contrast, just a stone's throw away, the next precinct that is not so fortunate is still standing forlornly waiting for its turn.  Its residents are looking wistfully across the road, watching with envy their neighbours who are enjoying lifts that stop at every floor and upgraded common areas, and asking when it will be their turn. 

 

     Across the country, there are many precincts and blocks of flats that have not been upgraded.  Realistically, are we able to upgrade them all, and over what

Column: 647

timeframe?  What is the capital expenditure required?  If our resources will be better deployed to fund other priority projects, I think we should start re-orientating the expectations of our residents.

 

Restructuring for affected Singaporeans

 

     On a related issue on restructuring for affected Singaporeans and what I call the four-roomer's problem, we went through a period of high growth with escalating property prices.  Now, we are faced with structural unemployment where some jobs may never return.  There are those who had geared too highly during the boom years and bought properties that are now beyond their means.  Their income has been slashed; some with income so low that they cannot even meet their daily household needs.  The cost of living remains high and they have accumulated arrears in HDB loan repayment, electricity bills, SC&CC, school fees, etc.  Although there is the need to retrain and upgrade their skills, some simply cannot get out of the rut.

 

     What are we doing to help them?  We are offering small hesitant measures of help - restructure their HDB loans for a few months, short-term financial assistance, subsidies for school fees, for fear that if we are too generous, more and more people will choose the easier option, leading us down the slippery slope to become a welfare state with an over-reliant population.  But these small measures are unlikely to solve their problem.

 

     Their main problem is housing.  They had made a major mistake and bought too big a flat which they cannot now afford due to their changed circumstances.  They need to downgrade to a smaller more affordable flat.  Even if they want to sell at the present market value, they will

Column: 648

not get much back after repaying the loan.

Even if they sell their present flat, with their present low income and with the new rules on HDB housing loans, it is unlikely that they will get a loan from the HDB or the commercial banks to buy the next flat.

 

     When it comes to means testing, they tend to fail.  Once the assessor sees "4-room" as the room type, their application for subsidy is put on one side.

 

     Sir, realistically, what can they do to get out of this rut?  Can we help them to downgrade, wipe their slates clean, lighten their burden, so that they can start afresh and move on?  We can do this as a one-off exercise to apply these measures to clear the historical cases, and are not applicable to new cases if we fear that more people will fall into this group and be reckless in making property purchases in future, thinking that the Government will always bail them out.

 

     Next, I would like to comment on some of the issues DPM spoke about in the Budget Statement.

 

Procreation - next generation of Singaporeans

 

     Many Members before me have spoken about more babies to be the next generation of Singaporeans.  I would like to also touch on this issue.  The declining birth rate has been discussed, debated and deliberated upon for a long time not just in the Government but also among the public.  Not replacing ourselves is a serious problem not just for the country but also the individual families.  Although we cannot over-emphasise the effects of the declining birth rate on our nation as a whole, we must also consider its negative effects on individuals and the family unit.

 

     To illustrate, let me tell you about a documentary I once saw on China Television about China's one-child policy. 

Column: 649

China, as we know, has the reverse problem of controlling her population, but the consequence of having only one child is similar in all countries.  In one segment of the programme, a young woman in her 20s was interviewed.  She said she had just started working and earning an income.  Being an only child, she has to support two parents and four aging grandparents, ie, parents of her parents.  If she married, her husband would probably be from a one-child family.  Hence, the two of them would have to support not only themselves but four parents and eight grandparents, and a baby, if they were to have a child of their own.  She said she was very depressed by the thought of that prospect.  This has serious financial implications on the young family and the state.

 

Enhancing competition: Power industry

 

     Next, on enhancing competition and the power industry.  Business people have been lamenting about our high electricity charges that add to the high cost of doing business in Singapore.  We rely on imported fuel oil and natural gas to generate electricity, and the prices of these commodities are beyond our control.  We do not have cheap domestic sources of coal or oil, nor large rivers to tap hydro-electricity, nor nuclear power stations.

 

     Sir, since the introduction of vesting contract on 1st January 2004 based on 65% of the system demand being allocated to the four generation companies, the vesting price for the month of January 2004 was $94.24 per megawatt hour (MWh) and the average pool clearing price was $66 per MWh.  The wholesale price of electricity, which is the weighted average of the vesting price and the pool price, had therefore fallen.  But given the high capital costs of the power plant and equipment, and the intrinsic costs of running and maintaining a power station, is such a low wholesale

Column: 650

price sustainable over the longer term?  Should the consumers be overjoyed and can they now revise their financial budgets with the expectation of lower charges for their electricity?

 

     Most of the large commercial and industrial contestable customers, including many of our SMEs, which had embraced retail market liberalisation, exercised choice and elected to be supplied by independent retailers were surprised to see their electricity bills in January.  Under the new electricity market rules and the contract they entered into with their retailers, payments for any excess volume under the vesting contract will be charged to them.  For the month of January, they ended up bearing an additional 12% on their bills.

 

     Under our market settlement rules, the extra payment that these contestable customers have to bear is paid to the generation companies.  The largest beneficiaries are the three large Temasek-owned gencos, one of them being Senoko, of which I am an external director.  But, in the longer term interest of our new electricity market, we are not overjoyed by this extra profit.  In fact, there are some industry concerns that the Government is trying to increase the profits of these gencos so that Temasek could get a better price for their divestment.  Sir, such speculation is detrimental not only to Temasek's divestment efforts but also to the good reputation of Singapore.

 

Foreign-sourced income

 

     My next point is on foreign-sourced income.  It is a good move that we are exempting individuals' foreign-sourced income.  Any money kept outside Singapore will not benefit Singapore.  Any money brought in, whether to invest in stocks and shares or to spend on a BMW, will contribute to our economy and bring about other benefits, direct or indirect,

Column: 651

whether in the form of vehicle taxes or adding more liquidity to our capital markets.

 

     To encourage the in-flow of this offshore money hitherto kept overseas, our rules have to be clear as to what is regarded as income earned in Singapore and, hence, subject to tax.  Otherwise, there will always be the fear that a few years after the offshore income is brought in, the tax authorities may question whether it was in fact earned in Singapore.  Such a risk would discourage people from bringing in their foreign-sourced income.

 

Tax exemption for new companies

 

     Sir, my next point relates to tax exemption for new companies.  When we allow full exemption from tax for the first $100,000 of normal chargeable income, excluding Singapore dividends, for each of the first three years of assessment within YA 2005 to YA 2009, we should be mindful of the risk of abuse.  In other countries where such "3-year tax free and 2-year half tax" exemption is available, businessmen have been quick to incorporate new companies to park their profits for the three years and, towards the end of the 3-year period, set up other new companies and divert profits to these newly set up companies to continue to enjoy the tax exemption.  Once the older companies have exhausted their 3-year exemption, they are then wound up.

 

Withholding tax on royalty payments

 

     My last point relates to withholding tax on royalty payments.  I fully agree that exploiting new knowledge and ideas is important for Singapore companies to compete internationally.  But why limit ourselves to using other people's ideas and intellectual property?  We should be bolder still and more optimistic about

Column: 652

Singapore-based companies' abilities to generate new ideas, and plan for the situation where Singapore companies will own and hold their own IPs, and other companies from other countries have to pay royalties to our Singapore IP owners.

 

     Presently, such royalty payments are subject to withholding tax in the country of the payer and are also taxed as income when the royalties are received or brought into Singapore.  This has forced many companies to engage creative tax advisers to park their IPs in tax haven countries and keep their royalty proceeds offshore.  This is not healthy.

 

     We should, therefore, have measures to encourage both Singapore homegrown companies and foreign companies that choose to use Singapore as their IP centre to own, hold and register their IPs in Singapore, thereby bringing revenue into our country.

 

     Sir, I support the motion.
