     Mr David T E Lim (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, if I may, I would like to approach this debate from a slightly different point of view to talk about some of the emotional aspects of policy-making.

 

Column: 653

     Sir, in our nation's next phase of development, we will need to harness everyone's economic contributions - from student to entrepreneur, from policy maker to homemaker.  To do this, we must make sure that our economic policies are right; and the provisions in this year's budget move us in that right direction. 

 

     But to overcome the challenges we face, we need more than just the right, rational policies.  We also need the emotional buy-in from everyone so that these policies can be effective.  Take, for example, a topical subject that has come up several times today and will come up again, that is, about making babies and raising children.

 

     Many good ideas have been raised about how to increase the number of babies born each year.  But the fundamental and most important question to address is whether young adult Singaporeans want babies.   If we want to look for reasons today why young couples do not want babies, there are many.  Essentially, they boil down to cost, time and lifestyles.  But how do we counter these reasons?  Logic will not.  Incentives cannot.   But emotions can.

 

     Incentives can raise birth rates, at least temporarily as our own experience has shown.  But at best, incentives can only make it easier for parents to have babies, and lower the cost of raising children.  And at worst, more and more incentives may leave young couples with the idea that children are a burden, and not a joy.  So I agree with Mr Tan Soo Khoon that the only compelling reason why we should bear with the pain, and the cost, and the inconvenience of having babies is the joy they bring.  This is an emotional motive, not an economic rationale.

 

     When my children were young, my happiest moment was when I came home

Column: 654

from work, they were there, rushing to the door to greet me.  Now as they grow up, my greatest joy is to see them mature - to see how they have become kind and sensitive in dealing with people, how they are confident of themselves, how they are able to argue perceptively.

 

     Sir, if we see babies as another claim on time, or an addition to costs, or an interference with lifestyles, then we will clamour for more and more incentives, and still they would not be enough.  But if we truly believe in the joy of children, then incentives help, but should no longer matter the most.  But even if we believe that we should have children because they bring us joy, there is a second consideration.  And that is whether we believe that we can give our children joy.  If we are honest with ourselves, the answer to this question depends on whether we are ourselves happy with our lives.  If we are, then we can believe that our children will also have happy lives.  But if we believe that life is getting harder, rather than better, then we would not think that our children's lives could be happier. These are fundamental questions of belief that each person must decide.

 

     The measures we are putting in place to restructure our economy are sensible and will make us stronger and more able to compete in the years ahead.  We have the skills, and systems and institutions to do many and great things, if we believe in them.  But we will achieve far less than our potential if our emotions are not right, and our heart is not in what we do.  It is not just about making babies.  But it extends to every area of public policy and governance.  Our students need to feel that learning is a joy, not a subject to be passed, or a drudgery to be endured.  Our entrepreneurs need to feel that they are heroes and not left-behinds, and be motivated by this feeling to attempt great things.  We need a civil and a civic society, where people believe that this is where their heart and home is.

 

Column: 655

     Such outcomes are helped by the right economic policies.  But we also need to develop our emotions as a nation.  We can achieve this by factoring in practical measures to uplift emotions in our policies.  These need not necessarily be big, radical policy shifts for now, but rather sensible adjustments to our existing robust frameworks.  We could encourage babies, for example, by the Government moving quickly to a five-day workweek, and building more family oriented infrastructure for weekends, so that we can enjoy our children, and our children can be happy and enjoy our company. 

 

     The most important need we have today as a nation is to nurture the heart of our people.  We can do this by using the money and the resources we have set aside in this budget in practical ways that uplift our emotions and human spirit.

 

     Sir, I support the Budget.

     Mr S Iswaran (West Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in this debate.

 

     Sir, I rise in support of the Budget for FY04. To me, this Budget is significant not so much for its specific announcements on expenditure and taxation policies, but more on the Finance Minister's outline of some core fiscal policies which will underpin the Government's public finance approach going forward in its stage of new development and competition that Singapore will face. In the course of the next few minutes, I hope to address some of those underlying principles.

 

     Sir, a recent report by a Morgan Stanley economist was headlined, "The FY 2004 Budget - extreme conservatism is puzzling".  I can understand that analyst's puzzle if you will, because he compares the surpluses that the

Column: 656

Government has accumulated over a period of growth to the deficits that it has run in the last three or so years, and draws the conclusion that the Government can spend more from its reserves and other sources in order to create more of a domestic economy. Some data that have been cited include the average surplus for the period FY1993 to FY2003, has been in the order of magnitude of about 13% of GDP for 2004, compared to the average deficit for the period FY2001 to FY2004 which is about 3.5% of 2004 GDP.  Put in another way, accumulated surplus was in the order of magnitude of about $130 billion, whereas the deficit was only in the order of magnitude of about $6 billion.  So why can the Government not spend more?

 

     Sir, I think there is some sympathy for that perspective both within this House and also in the general economy.  The Finance Minister himself has made an eloquent case as to why fiscal prudence has been the hallmark of this Government.  He has stressed the sound public finances which underpin Singapore's economic growth and resilience.  He has also highlighted the Government's willingness, in a sense, to have temporary deficits, as it has been the case in the last few years, without falling into the trap of permanent structural deficits.  These are sound principles which I fully support.  They are going to become even more important, especially the aspect of maintaining balanced budgets in an environment where competition is going to get more intense, having downward impact and pressure on the Government's revenue whilst expenditure needs are going to continously increase with an aging population and other social needs in the country.  Is a $0.7 billion deficit, which is about 0.4% of GDP 2004, extreme conservatism or is it a cautious first step with additional spending due with procreation-oriented measures and other policies that will be unfolding in the course of the year?

 

Column: 657

     My own view is that it is better to be cautious.  But I would like to hear the Finance Minister's elaboration on the Government's policy of fiscal prudence, and especially in managing it at a time when the economy is at the turning point and rising for growth.

   

     In the Finance Minister's outline of the policy on building a strong society, there were a few key themes which ran through all aspects that he addressed - education, healthcare, building the next generation and also on the aspect of saving for retirement.  I thought one of the key themes was the balance between the State and the individual in taking responsibility for one's own affairs. We are at an important juncture where there has been a great deal of presumptions on the part of many Singaporeans where the State will intervene, and intervene in many cases quite quickly, in order to look after their interests.  In an environment which imposes greater onus on the individual, not just take responsibility for himself, but also in terms of going out and creating wealth and opportunities in our country and beyond, that model is not relevant.  Indeed, we must expect that the centre of gravity must shift from the State to the individual, not precipitously, but in gradual measured steps, but certainly the direction must be clear.  I think that has become quite evident in the slew of underlying principles that the Finance Minister has announced in the course of this Budget debate. 

 

     The second aspect is where does State funding go?  The key point is that State funding should go where there is greatest benefit for Singapore as a whole.  In economic terms, it will be called the positive externality, meaning there are benefits that go beyond just the individuals, but to society in general.  A good example of that is primary and secondary education and basic healthcare.  Continued expenditure in this area and even increasing expenditure in this area is

Column: 658

an important plank for the Government in its future policies.

 

     The third theme that ran through is helping those who are in greatest need.  Hence, the discussion on the healthcare system and, in particular, means testing to decide whether and how much an individual should be entitled to in terms of subsidies from the Government.  These are all sound underlying principles to achieve social equity and economic efficiency in public finance.  But there are a few key concerns that I have because we are managing a transition from an economy in a high-growth phase with Government playing a very dominant role to an economy in a more challenging phase, and Government empowering individuals and corporations more to chart their destiny.

 

     In that context, one key element in all this change must be the preservation of choice.  Singaporeans must be free to choose.  If we take healthcare as an example, what level of healthcare do they want so that they can decide on how to spend their dollar?  Whether it is full cost, private, "A" class in our Government hospitals or subsidised healthcare at "C" class or some intermediate arrangement, all these options must be available to Singaporeans.  Then they can make rational choices as to how they want to allocate their budgets.

In that context, I was quite heartened to hear that the Government will ensure that even the well-off can use C-class wards or will access to C-class wards, although they may not perhaps enjoy the same level of subsidy.

 

     The second dimension is providing support.  When we make changes of this nature, asking individuals to take more ownership and responsibility, it is inevitable that some will fall through the cracks, and this is not because of any lack of trying or ill-intent on their part.  It could just be the result of the

Column: 659

circumstances that they find themselves in.  It is important, for example, in the context of university education, that we have adequate measures in place to help those who are going to have difficulties meeting their financial obligations, especially if they have to bear a higher portion of the cost.  We have talked a lot about loans and bursaries.  But for a young university student, at the age of, say, 20-21, taking out a loan, even if it is for a few tens of thousands of dollars, is a huge ball and chain around his or her neck and it can affect morale and perhaps even the choice of whether to go ahead with tertiary education.  The question is whether there are alternatives we can examine.  And what I would like to ask the Government to consider is the model that the Australians have adopted, which is to impose a tertiary tax on those who go through the university system so that for a period of time after they have graduated and when their earnings are about certain levels, they will pay a tax until they are deemed to have fulfilled their own financial obligation to the university education that they received.  That might achieve the twin objectives of, on the one hand, imposing greater financial ownership on individuals for their tertiary education and, at the same time not over-burdening the individual student, psychologically or financially, at the very outset of his or her tertiary education. 

   

     The third aspect, Sir, I would like to highlight is, keeping it simple and fair.  We have a system which is quite complex.  Buying a car in Singapore involves, for some people, quite complex econometric modelling - trying to anticipate COE prices, their movements, and how various Government policies will have an impact on these.  And, really these are very simple choices we should be allowed to make in our daily lives.  From that context, when we talk about the means test, it should also be simple,

Column: 660

but fair.  What do I mean by that?  When we consider some of the past Government assistance measures that have come in place, like CPF top-ups and so on, we have used housing type as the proxy for one's economic well-being and so the smaller your housing type, the greater the top-up you receive, or no top-up depending on how high the housing type is.  That is at best a crude measure and certainly when we are looking at it in the context of things like healthcare we should be very careful how we administer such criteria.

 

     Specifically, I would say that we should not be looking just at assets, we should be looking at flows of income that people have, in deciding what category they fall into in terms of socio-economic groups.  A good example would be older generation Singaporeans who might be living in landed property, but old landed property in some of the older estates in Singapore.  For these individuals, to make an argument that they are asset rich and they could also sell their house and pay for their medical cost - economically rational, but I think socially quite difficult to communicate and convince people.  So I would say that we need to strike a balance between the two, not totally disregard one's asset holdings, but find the way to strike a balance between that and the real income flows that individuals have, so that whatever means test we ultimately administer, will be seen as one that is fair.

   

     Sir, if I can just move to the point on building the next generation and procreation policies.  By outlining the Government's thinking on some underlying principles, but leaving out the details or specifics for later, the Finance Minister has, in the manner of speaking, left us all with a pregnant pause.  Fortunately, we only have to wait six months, till August, not the usual nine months, before the delivery of the full package.  But, Sir, I fully support the

Column: 661

principle that the Finance Minister has underlined and, in particular, the policy of aiming to produce the next generation of Singaporeans is vital because ultimately the thing will serve us not so well to have generated a whole group of young generation Singaporeans unless they have a deep commitment to this country and our future, which is collectively held.  But I do have some thoughts on what can be done in this respect.  Mr David Lim said that it is an emotional, not an economic issue.  I agree.  But this is the Budget, and since we are talking about dollars and cents, let me just share with you a quick back of the envelope calculation.

   

     If our procreation policy is able to generate 5,000 more births a year, and each of these children goes on to contribute to the economy at the average GDP per capita, let us say, S$20,000 a year, that is quite conservative, in fact, the number is higher.  And, let us say their working life is 30 years, a quick ballpark calculation, that cohort would contribute something like S$3 billion to our economy over a 30-year life-span.  I think this is a conservative number.  So investing about 10-15% of that future benefit in a generation of young Singaporeans today is not bad mathematics and I would, therefore, urge the Finance Minister to give the Minister-in-charge maximum latitude to exercise his discretion in this respect.

 

     Quite apart from the future benefits, the other point to note is spending in this particular sector is likely to be more domestically oriented because a lot of services are generated within the economy here.  So the multiplier for the local economy is also likely to be far greater than in some other fiscal policies. 

   

     Where should the money be spent?  First, a plea.  Please do not distinguish between the first, second or third child.  Neither should the parents of children of

multiple births be penalised.  Every child is precious, not just to the parents, but to all of us.  For the parents, each additional child adds to their responsibilities and challenges, almost exponentially.  I speak from very recent personal experience when I just have my third child.  And, whoever coined the phrase, "sleeping like a baby", clearly had no idea what he is talking about.  So what more when you have multiple births!  When they have two or three children of the same age, demanding their attention, I think we should empathise with those parents and make it easier for them.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, I congratulate the Government on proposing yet another prudent and forward-looking Budget that is both pro-business and pro-future-generation.  Singapore is going through a very difficult transition in an unpredictable global arena.

 

      As I see it, the churning of the economic restructuring process, the relaxation of political and    cultural controls, the emphasis on creative learning in our schools, the encouragement of a participatory civic culture, and the opening up of our borders not only to trade and investments but also to foreign labour, are all inter-related in ways that produce positive outcomes in some situations, but could also be perceived to be negative in other senses.

 

     Sir, I propose to touch on three aspects of the change process that are upon Singapore.  The first aspect has to do with demography in general, and a declining birth rate in particular.  The second aspect has to do with the aging population, and the third aspect is on the professionals, managers and executives group.

 

     Sir, demographic changes in the population are an ever recurring theme in the life of any nation.  What is critical though is the idea that demographic forces ought to be shaped and brought under certain degrees of control in order that certain long-term national objectives may be met.  However, national objectives can conflict with individual objectives.  It is important that the Government treads softly and gently in finding modes of reconciliation between long-term national needs and the immediate term preferences expressed by individuals.  So, before we even begin to find ways and means to decide whether our procreation policies need revising, we

Column: 677

have to first and foremost satisfy ourselves that such a reconciliation is possible.

 

    At first glance, we may brush aside the need for such an exercise, and simply argue that we should just plunge straight into tinkering with our policy tool-kit.  However, if we do not ask ourselves some fundamental questions over this most fundamental of issues, we would simply repeat the same mistakes of the past.

 

     In the past, we had tried to fight the decline of our birth rate by taking out what we thought was the most effective weapon in our armoury - financial incentives.  Yet, this approach has not provided the results we have been looking for.  From 1.7 in the 1980s, we are now at 1.24 children born to each female.  That makes us wonder why a supposedly materialistic citizenry has not responded to incentive schemes that were financially driven.  An immediate analysis would be that financial incentives are not enough.  And, indeed, that is what some Singaporeans are saying, judging by the feedback of participants at feedback forums.  And these Singaporeans may be right!  But, in my view, only partly so! 

 

    For the chasm between the national imperative and individual ambitions is more profound than a simple two plus two equation.  At the national level,

we are well aware of the need to rejuvenate our economy.  We need a certain critical mass of a citizen base that is intelligent, productive, educated, and committed if we want to maintain our competitiveness in the new economy.  We need that mass to nurture our local small-medium enterprises to maturity before they take to the jungles of an ultra-competitive global market-place.  We also need a critical mass of able-bodied male soldiers to help guard and defend the sovereignty of this nation.  At the same time, we also need that critical mass of productive

Column: 678

Singaporeans to help constitute the tax base upon which the infrastructure of the nation continues to be of such standards as to appeal to the global investment community.  We also need that critical mass of solid-base citizens whose tax revenues ensure that we maintain healthy fiscal balances.

 

     All of what I have just cited are indeed national imperatives.  In fact, they are absolutely necessary if we hope to be able to survive and sustain ourselves, our vibrancy, our security, and our prosperity as a nation.

 

     Yet, at another level, individual Singaporeans have their own set of imperatives.  For example, some Singaporeans define quality life as one that is free from the obligations of parenthood. To this group of Singaporeans, having children hinders them from enjoying life to the full, with all its possibilities and potentialities.  Other Singaporeans want to have children, but are also in search of a better life for themselves and their offspring. To this group of Singaporeans, having more than one child would materially detract them from achieving the many goals that they set for themselves in life.

 

     One variant of this group of Singaporeans are those who feel that having more children than they can reasonably afford is an irresponsible thing to do because they are not able to give to their children the financial and time resources that they need in their lives.  More often than not, this group will give grouse to their feeling that the Government is preaching an inconsistent message: "On the one hand, they want us to work, on the other hand, they want us to have children.  How can that be done?  It is difficult because companies these days are too demanding of our time, and the cost of living in Singapore is just too steep to have more than one."  There are yet other Singaporeans who face infertility

Column: 679

problems in their reproductive lives, and having children is biologically impossible or very difficult to achieve.

 

     Because the nature of the problem is complex, to my mind, the solution should likewise be multi-faceted.  Firstly, at some stage in our national life, we have got to define for ourselves what quality life is.  Back in the 1960s, when the Government attempted to sort out our then demographic problems, we had a campaign: stop-at-two.  The stop-at-two campaign portrayed having lots of children as incompatible with conducive living in a modern metropolis like Singapore.  It did not just put out financial incentives for mothers to have less children, but went on to alter the consciousness of Singaporeans concerning the hassles of having too many children.

 

     Now, I think that Members would agree with me when I say that the campaigning methods of the past will not be as effective in persuading a more sophisticated citizenry of today, particularly when the content of the campaign touches on as personal issue as that of procreation.  On the other hand, I also think that Members would agree with me when I say that the broad incentivising methods of the past will not work as they did years ago.  Singaporeans have more choices today.  To be sure, quality life includes material well-being and a comfortable and secure financial life.  But quality of life is more than just that.  It must also include values that transcend financial well-being.

 

     The Singapore 21 project is a commendable one in that it seeks to define who we are as a people, and what we are becoming as a nation.  My feeling though is that the Singapore 21 project has still not touched on what quality life ought to be for Singaporeans as

Column: 680

individuals and as families.  As a result of our inability to recast a compelling vision of who we are as a people and what quality life is, many Singaporeans still define the procreation issue in terms of the same old divides.

 

     I do not propose to have all the answers of the nature or content of another campaign.  But I do know  that we have got to genuinely engage ourselves as a nation to discuss what the Singapore quality life is about. And the discussion should not be so boxed in as to define quality life in purely individualistic terms, but also encompass an awareness of how the nation's struggle with this issue will inevitably have an impact on whether Singaporeans will continue to secure the conditions for quality life in the future.

 

     The nation must go into a soul-searching process, and that means that there must be some shift of our cultural values, along with that of our policies.  The Government can lead the way in reshaping our cultural landscape, but that soul-searching process should never stop with the Government.  Indeed, if the campaigning process were to begin with the Government, and stop with the Government, it will not reach right into the hearts of Singaporeans.

 

     Short of cultural change, policies may, at best, arrest the decline somewhat, but will not reverse.  As such, may I suggest that we adopt a values-driven approach in our attempt to reverse our declining birth rate.  The values-driven approach will be holistic and strategically focused, but what sets it apart from other forms of synergy is that it is suffused with a re-orientation of an understanding of what life is about, and what children are about.  As mentioned earlier, I do not propose here to define what the vision of life and the vision of the people we ought to become and the types of children we

Column: 681

ought to be raising. What I am proposing here is a Government-led, but civic-group and community-sustained effort at reorienting our moorings as a nation to one that is more community-minded and one that defines quality life in material and non-material terms.

 

    What I have just outlined is addressed to our approach for an overarching strategy.  What I would like to do now is to look into the re-workings of substantive policy areas.  Based on the feedback of various groups, a few things suggest themselves to me.  Before I delve into them at some detail, may I suggest that these policies be targeted at the different groups of Singaporeans, whose differing attitudes to parenting I have outlined earlier in this speech.  For Singaporeans who are set on not having children at all, I think there is not much that we can do to persuade them to do otherwise, other than to respect their right of choice.  I do not think that getting them to pay more taxes is a fair way to deal with the issue for the simple reason that the Government incentives that would accrue to those who want to have more children would have been paid for from out of the tax coffers anyway.  In other words, as far as revenues and expenditures are concerned, those who wish to have children or more of them, would already have enjoyed the benefits that would be extended to them.  Some portion of the benefits that they would get to enjoy would already have been paid for by those who do not wish to have children.

 

     As far as the wish to not have children is concerned, I propose that the Government start to inculcate from a very young age the desirability of having children.  This would mean that we would have to target children with the message that having children is one good way towards fulfilment in life, and that having more than one child would not materially detract them from enjoying quality life.

 

Column: 682

     At the cultural level, we should attempt to mould young minds towards the idea of shared responsibility in the home front.  When traditionalist attitudes are uprooted from a very young age in the home and community as well as at schools, our young people will grow up to appreciate the necessity of shared responsibility and the young women of the future will not mentally equate child rearing with drudgery for themselves, but is a joy shared by both husbands and wives. At the same time, when paternalistic attitudes are uprooted from a young age, future male bosses will be less likely to be prejudicial towards the needs of working mothers.

 

     And, speaking of prejudices against working mothers, I would like to raise my concern here with regard to the recent proposal of the Ministry of Finance to extend the maternity leave of working mothers from eight weeks to, maybe, sixteen weeks or even more. The proposal has it that the Government would be willing to shoulder the wage costs of employing these working mothers for the extra period being proposed, subject to a ceiling, which has yet to be decided upon.  However, before attempting such a move, the Government would do well to bear in mind that there are costs that employers have to bear besides the cost of the wages being paid to replacement workers.  The main cost that comes immediately to mind is that of the disruption to the work process that may be caused by an extended period of absence from work. The disruption may come in the form of hiring temporary but less experienced workers to cover the duties of the employee on maternity leave.  This disruption may cause employers to think twice about hiring mothers, and the practice of discrimination in hiring may become widespread.  If our female workers catch wind of such discriminatory practices being endemic in the workplace, they may be reluctant to have children or

Column: 683

to have more children than what they already have.

 

     To counteract this problem, some may even propose that the policy includes giving males paternity leave as well. This will then ensure a level-playing field between males and females in the process of job recruitment and selection.  In other words, our policy should address the issue of the declining birth rate from the employment practices front as well.

 

     For those groups of Singaporeans who feel that having children, or having more of them, is good but who feel that they have to cope with the very many demands that will come their way if they decide to have children, a few policy changes can be considered.  Companies should be given tax rebates or write-offs for providing childcare facilities at or near the workplace. Alternatively, companies may also enjoy these rebates or write-offs if they provide their female employees with subsidies for enrolling their children at childcare centres. These incentives attract companies to invest in pro-family programmes, instead of only looking at procreation as cost issues.

 

     For female Singaporeans who feel that taking a few years off work to look after their children will only serve to set back their careers, I feel that companies should be provided with the incentives to retrain these women if need be, and to be provided with all the assistance they need to more easily reintegrate their female employees into the work setting. Practically speaking, we may even put a timeframe (such as three years) in which companies get to enjoy these subsidies.

 

     The civil service should set the tone for the rest of the economy.  If the civil service does not send out the appropriate message, then I think that the effort would have been wasted.  From the

Column: 684

feedback of various groups that I have talked to, it would appear that the civil service could do more to fully implement the Government's policies to make it easier for women to be reintegrated to work.

 

    Another option would be to lower the cost of employing maids.  Reduce the maid levy and offer working mothers maid subsidies so that they can employ maids to help look after the children while they are out.  Our policy should be to remove key obstacles currently discouraging Singaporeans from having children.

 

     Another contributory factor to the decline in birth rate is infertility. Infertility rates are increasing in Singapore. Often related to stress and the general pace of life, couples must be encouraged to seek treatment. Infertility treatment needs to be made more affordable and we need to remove the stigma that still lingers. Men in particular must be encouraged to seek infertility treatment and counselling. A public information service needs to be put in place.

 

     The second aspect of our demographic issue is on the ageing population.   Singapore now has the second highest number of senior citizens in Asia. Employers are still reluctant to employ people over 50.

Too often, they are stereotyped as being less trainable and not receptive to new ideas.  Research, however, indicates otherwise.  As such, we need to initiate more public awareness campaigns to acquaint employers with the facts.  Measures that could promote such a message and convey our sincerity include increasing the retirement age, mounting "back-to-work programmes", and retraining.  Older workers are a valuable resource and, as such, should not be wasted.

 

     Finally, Sir, I would like to speak on a different issue, ie, that of job creation for professionals, middle executives who are 

Column: 685

over 50 and who have been laid off by companies during the retrenchment exercise of recent times.  The Budget has not addressed this directly.

 

     Sir, many of the jobs for which the PMEs have been trained will not be coming back to Singapore.  That, Sir, is structural unemployment.  And, for many of those professional and middle-executive managers who also happen to be in their 50s, they will have to reckon with age discrimination in the hiring process as well.  If we add to that the hesitance of employers to hire those whom they think to be well paid, then the triple whammy that this group of people are suffering may just be too overwhelming.

 

     And, with no prospect in sight for any short-term recovery of their previous positions, I think we need to see if the Government can do something to facilitate their reintegration into the labour force.  Quite obviously, the chief means to prepare them for reintegration is that of retraining.  Of retraining and job matching, much has been said, and I do not wish to revisit the same ground here.  What I do wish to raise though is the possibility of directly creating jobs for this group of formerly employed professionals and middle executives through means of pooling their shared resources.  I know that the Singapore Professionals and Executives Co-operative (SPEC) has already taken the first step in this direction, but there is much more to be done to get this idea to gain acceptance among Singaporeans. 

 

     The Government is already trying to move our economic base to one that is not solely reliant on MNCs and GLCs, but to help nurture home-grown small and medium enterprises to become global players.  This is a very commendable effort.  However, I think that there are alternative forms of employment and job

Column: 686

creation, one of which is to get people to pool their resources to start up co-operatives that can venture into areas like infant care, finance, travel and tourism, retail, restaurants, information technology, and so on.

 

     By pooling their resources, these formerly-employed PMEs are not only able to raise capital, but also contribute their vast expertise, experience, networks, and knowledge in the running of such co-operatives.  I strongly encourage Singaporeans to support the rise of more such co-operatives in Singapore, and here I call upon our Government to lend its support by helping to facilitate the cultivation and nurture of such enterprises.

 

     One area that the Government can help facilitate these co-operatives is to extend to them many of the schemes that are currently being administered by SPRING Singapore.  For example, assistance can be rendered to these co-operatives to secure loan facilities at attractive rates of interest; technical assistance can be rendered by the various Government agencies;  learning programmes can be funded;  and technology transfer linkages can be effectuated by bringing these co-operatives and multinational or Government-linked companies together.

 

     I would like to share this observation made by Rodrik in 1997 where it succinctly summarises the responsibility of the state to its people:  

 

     "It is not whether you globalise €¦ it is how you globalise.  The world market is a source of disruption and upheaval as much as it is an opportunity for profit and economic growth ... It has now become commonplace to point out that market-oriented reforms require social safety nets to prevent people from falling through the cracks €¦ The provision of social insurance is an important component of market reforms - it cushions the blow on those most severely affected €¦ and it avoids a backlash

Column: 687

against the distributional and social consequences of globalisation."

 

     Sir, the point is that whilst we make changes, we must at the same time ensure that we preserve the social compact in the transition.  Generally, we agree on the need to lend a helping hand to the least well-off and the most vulnerable in society.  But there is much less certainty or agreement about the role of the Government beyond that.  Therefore, I see that we have an obligation to the PMEs that we cannot deny: an obligation to give the unemployed PMEs a chance to be economically active again.  So long as they cannot be re-engaged economically again, we will have a potentially explosive force to deal with.

 

     So, let us welcome the emergence of diverse forms of business enterprises in Singapore, and let us encourage Singaporeans to join with each other to take the initiative to create jobs for themselves.  Let us also send out signals that this Government is there to facilitate the process along, to render the necessary assistance, if such be needed, and to stand alongside Singaporeans as they seek ways and means to carve out niches for themselves in the uncertain times ahead.

 

     On this note, I support the motion.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development and Minister for Defence (Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, 2004 is an exciting year for Singapore.  Around us, elections are all about.  In Malaysia, Indonesia and Taiwan, elections have reached a feverish pitch.  From afar, we have the elections in the States.  Many of us in Singapore watch these elections with great interest, because the outcome of any one of these elections will have a big impact on our

Column: 688

policies.  At home, Sir, bets are changing fast on when the new Prime Minister in Singapore will take over.  Still, in spite of all the talk that the new Prime Minister will be elected by Members of Parliament, I know of no bookmaker who is offering bets on the new man or woman.

 

     Sir, while the political transition offers no surprises, the economic transition is far less predictable.  We are definitely recovering from a long economic downturn.  Our economy appears to be growing well.  The question is whether this growth will translate into new jobs, and what kind of jobs.  And Mdm Ho Geok Choo is worried that the unemployed who are in their late 40s will be permanently unemployed.  Will the unemployment rate fall overall, or will it remain at the present level?

 

     Sir, only one month ago, the US administration, no doubt encouraged by financial analysts, not economists, was almost certain that the continued economic growth in the States would bring about the end of the job famine.  The latest February reports proved them terribly wrong.  The data confirm what serious labour economists had feared all along, ie, that in spite of the good economic growth, 2004 in the States is likely to be another year of jobless and joyless growth.  The unemployment rate today in the States stays at 5.6%.  The real unemployment rate is much higher than that because the long-term unemployed have opted out of the job market.  So, the employment rate has actually fallen.  Today, the debate between John Kerry and George Bush, Jr, is not how to create new jobs.  It is how to stem the flow of jobs to India and China.  Hence, the heated debates on Capitol Hill on legislating against outsourcing of jobs. 

 

     Sir, some economists in Singapore think what happened in the States will also happen in Singapore.  The Minister

Column: 689

for Finance did not offer substantial personal goodies, although he offered quite substantial goodies to companies.  But I think the Minister for Finance did a good job.  He gave a good unexciting Budget.  Many may be disappointed because there are no fireworks like personal rebates, tax cuts and reliefs.  For the last few years, we have seen a lot of fireworks in this area because moving ahead from 2001 to 2004 were uncertain times.  The Minister for Finance gave a Budget which he thinks will match the growth this year.  He is confident that the growth will be respectable. 

 

     And I share his conviction.  I share it because Singapore is quite different from the States.  In the case of Singapore, we have seen substantial changes in the economy, structural changes which the United States need not have gone through or did not go through.  After the Asian crisis of 1997, the economy has restructured.  Our wages have come down substantially.  CPF rates have also come down.  Land costs - Mr Inderjit Singh is not here - have come down very substantially.  Taxes have come down.  The once mighty Singapore dollar, which MAS defended with all its might, has also come down.  Most of all, expectations have also come down.  People are willing to take lower paying jobs, work longer hours.  All these mean that we have been right-sized.  Singapore is now ready to grow once more.  But we need opportunities.  But at least we are ready.

 

     Second, Sir, there is no stopping the outsourcing of jobs from the USA.  Even as the politicians on Capitol Hill debate in the Congress, more jobs will flow out to Asia, India and China, and Singapore will no doubt catch some of these jobs, if not all of them.  We are no longer expensive.  We are very educated, and I think we are becoming very hungry again.

 

     Third, we are small, unlike the USA.  And small is an advantage.  Although we

Column: 690

are small, we are cohesive, which means we punch above our collective size of three to four million people.  Small means we can move faster, fly further, and bounce up quicker. 

 

     Fourth, Singapore is one of the most wired places in the world.  I do not just mean electronically.  I also mean mentally.  Geographically and culturally, we are also close to the places where action is taking place - in India and China.  These two big engines of economic growth will pull us along just fine.  We have learnt to dance with the lion; we can also fly with the dragon.  Intellectually, we are on the same wavelength with the western world, particularly the Americans and the Europeans.  The fact that we speak mostly in English today is telling in itself.  We are truly at the crossroads of the world. 

 

     Hence, I think this gloom and doom that some Singaporeans talk about, that the best days are behind us, is really quite mistaken, quite unnecessary.  We have had more than 30 years of good growth, and only seven years of not-so-good growth.  I think it is more than what any one young country could have hoped for.  We should think it this way: the worst is behind us, the days ahead can only be better.  But in order to catch some of the jobs that could be coming beyond India and China to Singapore, we will first have to change some mindsets. 

 

     For a long time, Sir, we thrived in this region because we speak English, unlike our neighbours.  They speak English, but it is not their main administrative language, not their legal language.  And this gave us a decisive edge in the past.  But no longer.  When Mr Lee Kuan Yew opened up our borders and put out a red carpet to MNCs in the 60s, he actually went against the economic advice and political tide of the day.  The prophets of post-colonialism preached closed-door self-sufficiency.  We did the opposite. 

Column: 691

We opened up.  So, even though Singaporeans spoke less than good English, the world beat a path to our doors.  Why?  Because we were the most hospitable in the region.  They were looking for a low-cost place.  They could not go to India; India's doors were closed.  They could not go to China.  China talked about socialism and communism.  The third-world, they were all caught up in the "merdeka" or independence movement.  So, they came here.  But today the world is borderless.  Communism is in form but not in substance.  Trade and services flow uninhibited between countries, and everybody speaks English.  We are 3 to 4 million in Singapore.  We claim that we speak English.  China has 1,300 million or 1.3 billion people.  One percent of that speak English is 13 million.  So, it is a substantial number of people in China today who can speak English.  I do not have the numbers, but perhaps more than 3 to 4 million people can speak effectively in English and Mandarin. 

 

     Sir, our labour cost will never be as low as India's.  But assuming that it could go as low - God forbid - we would still not be able to attract to Singapore the kind of jobs that have gone to India.  Our problem is really our spoken language.  And for a long time we think that it does not matter what we speak, so long as we get the job done.  In the world of manufacturing, we do not have to speak.  In fact, if we go to a clean room, we are all masked up.  We are not allowed to speak.  But things have changed.  A lot of the outsourced jobs from America to India require real-time voice communications or talking.  And many people dismiss these as low-paying jobs, eg, telephone operators, telemarketers, or maybe somebody calling DPM to buy insurance.  But actually it goes beyond that.  Many of these are actually very high-value jobs, for example, lawyers in India masquerading as consultants, giving advice on

Column: 692

international law; software programmers going on real-time with Silicon Valley's programmers to talk about how to debug or frame a software; medical specialists interpreting mammograms

and x-rays over the telephone, giving advice to their clients in the States. All these are high-tech jobs, behind the phone, at the end of the line is a very qualified Indian, speaking impeccable English.

 

     They also have the talent to speak like an American. If we want a southern accent, they give it to us.  If we want a northern accent, they give it to us.  Even if we can find as many Singaporeans who are as qualified as the Indians, which is, of course, a dream, we will still lose out because we do not speak English like that. We do not have to speak like the Americans, but we must speak English that is intelligible.  In order to poise ourselves to catch some of these high quality outsourced jobs, we really need to declare war on Singlish.  Unfortunately, the local English sitcoms flourish on Singlish.  The more Singlish spoken on a local English sitcom, the more popular the rating.  I think that is doing us in. 

 

     The English spoken on Channel NewsAsia today bears absolutely no resemblance to the English spoken in this House, or on the streets and in the schools. So when I heard the Ministry of Education saying that X% of Singaporeans speak English at home and therefore, cannot be expected to do well in Chinese, I find it a bit disturbing because clearly, the statement means X% in Singlish.  I do not see the correlation why, if we speak Singlish, we cannot do well in Chinese.  I grant that if we speak received pronunciation in English, we might have some problems. 

 

     I have been following the debate on the learning of Chinese in Singapore.  I think it is something we have got to fix because China is another one big economic engine that we cannot afford to

Column: 693

ignore.  Even if we do not see it, we can hear the humming.  I think it is very naive, when I read some of the Straits Times' Forum pages' readers, saying business is business, the Chinese will have to speak English because it is an international language.   Yes, Chinese can speak English.  Many of them can, and those who cannot are learning English with diligence. That could be history.  For over 200 years, the Chinese have been trampled upon by the west. They have never forgotten the humiliation.  Today, a resurgent China is speaking their language, be it the Chinese language or trade language, or the language of diplomacy or economics on Chinese terms.

    One example is the recent ruling that they enacted on the sale of software. The new rule says that if we do not allow the software to be source-code open for Chinese programmers to write or to edit, then that software cannot be sold in China. This is one way where they are changing the rules.  In manufacturing, for example, they are also setting new standards which the Chinese feel comfortable, in other words, standards which they are superior in.  We have to manufacture to their standards, otherwise, we cannot sell our manufactured products in China.  Does it matter?  I think it does.  Can any supplier afford to ignore a market of 1.3 billion consumers?  In short, China is now saying today that, "We have the market, you want my business, you are welcome, but you speak my language."

 

     I would like to encourage my fellow Singaporeans to learn Chinese and learn it well. Contrary to popular belief in the English media, it is not too difficult a language to learn. To master it is a

Column: 694

different issue. To learn it, it is not so difficult. We have got to remember that there are hundreds of millions of very clever people around the world who are good in English. If we are one of them, it is really no big deal.  But there are not so many people, maybe tens of millions who are effectively bilingual - English and Chinese - and who are clever up here [indicating].  If we are lucky to count ourselves as one of those people, I think we can make a good living, bridging the west with China.

 

     Sir, many educated English elites lament that it is difficult to learn Chinese. Why?  Because they themselves do not speak Chinese.  I think this should not itself be a problem. The simple answer to parents who do not speak English at home or cannot speak English is basically to first send them to a PAP PCF and, secondly, to a neighbourhood primary school.  I speak Chinese but I am never home to speak to my children in Chinese.  Like most MPs, we leave home before they wake up and we go back after they have gone to bed.  In my case, my wife does not speak a word of Chinese because she never studied in Singapore not one single day. When I am at home, I do not speak Chinese.  I speak English.  Hence, my family is in the same position as many English-educated parents who find it difficult to encourage their children to speak Chinese.  So it was a conscious decision to enrol our children in a neighbourhood school just near to where we live and the results are most encouraging.  My children picked up Mandarin like little ducks to water.  They found it absolutely easy.  Why?  Because in that school, all the Chinese students speak Mandarin. They come from Mandarin-speaking homes. They watch Mandarin programmes, they sing Chinese songs, they play Chinese games.  In such an environment, Sir, it is impossible not to speak and write Chinese.  We are convinced that we did the right thing, at least up to now because my friends, some

Column: 695

of whom are in this House, warned me that if I send my children to some of the branded name schools, my children might not speak Chinese.  I asked them why. They said because in the named schools, the children speak English and they come from middle-income, English-speaking homes, even though the school may carry a Chinese label.

 

     My advice to parents who think that their children would have problems learning Chinese is to do the simple thing by sending them to the nearest neighbourhood school.  All primary schools in Singapore follow the same syllabus.   When it comes to PSLE, they all take a common examination.  All schools are structured to teach more or less in the same way.  I believe that if a child is academically clever, he or she will do well in PSLE, whatever school he or she attends.  If a child is not so academically well-endowed, it is better for him or her to go to a neighbourhood school because the environment there is more friendly and, at the same time, he or she can pick up Mandarin.  Look at it objectively, look at all the branded schools, not all the children go to the top four schools - RI, RGS, Nanyang Girls and Chinese High.  Conversely, if you look at the background of these students in these four schools, you find many of them come from neighbourhood schools.

 

     Recently, the English media was flooded with letters from parents whose children suffered from learning Chinese. Even today, the Straits Times' Forum page ran two long letters.  I suspect that there is real angst among the English-educated. But the problem, I suspect, is confined to the English-educated Chinese elites.  It is not a problem with HDB heartlanders.  While I empathise with their problem, I think they should not be too afraid.  The Ministry of Education has made some changes and I agree with

Column: 696

those changes.  The University of Singapore enrols undergraduates who cannot speak English well.  Many foreign students who come to our universities need extensive remedial English lessons. So why do we lock out Singapore students who are not good in Chinese?  We should allow these students who do not do well in Chinese, to enrol into the university. There is no need to discriminate them against their inability to master the language. The marketplace of jobs will ultimately discriminate against them one way or the other.

 

     For the vast majority of Chinese Singaporeans, the learning of Chinese is not a big issue.  In fact, Chinese is widely spoken on the university campuses.  It is, in fact, the preferred language of choice of a vast majority of students.  I know because I have been living in the university campus, not teaching there, for 13 years.  I stayed on top of the canteen. I went there quite often and I mixed with the students.  I saw them at the bus-stops, I gave them lifts.  I spoke with them in Chinese. They taught me many Chinese phrases.  They sang in Chinese and talked in Chinese. With a thriving community of Chinese mainland undergraduates now on both campuses, I am sure more students will speak good Mandarin.

 

     Sir, if we look at the TV viewership ratings as well as the radio listenership ratings, we will not be surprised to find the phenomena that Chinese is the preferred language of the Chinese community, contrary to all the letters that have been appearing in the English media. The viewership on Channel 8 is always higher than the viewership on Channel 5 and that of Channel U is higher than that of Channel I.  Some years ago, a media specialist told me that local English sitcoms would receive higher ratings than Chinese sitcoms.  I asked why.  He said that the English-educated actors on the English sitcoms are more academically

Column: 697

qualified so they can learn the tricks of the trade and bring their art to a better form for the audience.  I am not sure whether he was right. I demurred.  But the results vindicated me.  Even though there are no more Chinese schools, all of us speak English of one form or another in schools. Chinese students in English schools today still prefer to watch Chinese programmes, sing Chinese songs and play Chinese games.

 

     I do not watch TV but I read in the press that one Chinese sitcom, Holland Village, received such high viewership that on some episodes, the viewership was close to one million people.  An MP's wife told me recently that after watching the long running series, she was inspired to re-learn her Chinese which she has forgotten and did not learn seriously when she was in school.  I think this problem of learning Chinese in schools for Chinese students should be placed in the right perspective.  It is a problem for some, but it is not a problem for all. 

 

     Today, one Straits Times' reader suggested that to make it fun, teachers should tell stories in schools instead of asking students to do assessments, listen to Chinese pop music, talk about pop stars, etc.  I think she has a point there, but all these multi-media aids are actually available on the TV. Obviously, this parent does not allow the child to watch Channel 8 or Channel U.  I think it is not quite necessary for the teacher to repeat what is happening in the pop world, music or movie world in the classroom.  The Chinese has a saying, "san ren cheng hu", which means that if three persons talk about something which did not happen, bystanders will think something actually has happened.  All this talk about Chinese being a very difficult language to learn is doing us harm.  It is not just a language issue.  It is an economic issue.  It is the survival of the future issue.  For Singapore to tap into the fast-growing market of China, we should learn the language

Column: 698

seriously.   Personally, I do not lose sleep over all this talk that Chinese is difficult to learn, that we should not learn it or we should not allow the children to suffer anymore.  Kiasu Singaporeans will know what to do.  The marketplace of jobs will decide whether Chinese is important or not. 

 

     Sir, the more intractable problem which has been talked about in this House is the low birth rate and the consequent problem of a greying population.  Minister Khaw Boon Wan is not here but he pointed out correctly that Singapore's healthcare problem is not a serious one and that our healthcare is one of the best in the world because of many reasons - the share of GDP is low, there are few admissions to the hospitals and hospital stay is also short.  This is no doubt due to good administration and policy on the part of the Ministers in charge.  But there is also a very important demographic factor that underlies all these good statistics because we were a young nation and we are still relatively a young nation.

     In another 10 years, when the post-war baby boomers reach retirement age, we will see.  Inevitably, there will be more admissions, stays in hospitals will be longer, and the challenge then is really how to prevent expenditure on healthcare from ballooning too big.  I am sure this problem is well taken care of.  The underlying problem is that if we have a large pool of old people to take care of it is still not a serious problem if we have enough young people to carry them.  But we do not have young people coming forward to take care of the older people that are becoming old.  The reasons are plenty.  They have been seriously discussed in the media and in this House.  I am confident that, Minister Lim Hng Kiang will come out with a good proposal.  But whatever we do, we should not try to use money to buy babies because using money to buy babies is only a short fix for a long-term problem.  In the longer term,

Column: 699

we really need to change the environment.  Changing the environment is the key to sustainable solution to more births.  Many people say that Singaporeans are so busy that they have no time to make babies and that when the babies come they have no time to nurture the babies, no time to look after the babies.  There is a grain of truth in all these. 

 

     Sir, MINDEF has several overseas air detachments, one in France, several in the States.  If you look at the behaviour of our airmen out there you will find that it is quite different from what they do here.  Basically, they have a baby boom there.  Last year, I was up in Arizona and saw some of the airmen there.  I have never seen so many pregnant wives and young babies.  It is not a big detachment and I feel happy for them.  These are young families there, training very seriously to become Apache pilots and engineers and technicians.  So even as they train, they find time to make babies.  But obviously the environment there is conducive and I urge the Government to put in place some of the environment that encourage babies to come about.

     Mr Ang Mong Seng (Hong Kah) (In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, at a time when our economy is beginning to recover, the Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lee has given us a very prudent Budget and urged us to tighten our belts so that we can face the challenges ahead.  This is a very wise decision. 

 

     Although my grassroots leaders and residents have told me that there is nothing special about this Budget, I told them that at this crucial time, we have to be very prudent in dealing with our economy so that we can have good long term strategies to compete with other

Column: 700

countries.  I would like to speak on a few aspects. 

 

     Firstly, on tax incentives.  I fully agree with the Government's focus on helping the needy ones by topping up the CPF accounts of those who are in need.  We are helping our old people so that they can have enough in their Medisave accounts for their needs in the old age.  But we know that we are facing an aging problem and, because of the small family structure, many old people are facing a lot of problems, particularly when they are single.  There are more and more old people who have no one to depend on.  So the Government is spending more time and effort to look after them.  This is good.  But, in our society, there are people who show care and concern for the old people and have the love to adopt them and allow these old folks to stay with them. I think this is very good indeed.  In fact, there are a few such cases in my constituency. Children who maintain their parents enjoy tax relief from $5,000 to $8,000.  I feel that the Government should consider granting tax relief also to those charitable persons who adopt these old people and allow them to stay in their house.      Secondly, on assistance to the SMEs.  In restructuring our economy, we have adjusted our CPF contribution rates, and we are also promoting flexible wage system.  This is the Government's effort to help cut down business costs.  But, compared to the other countries in Asia, such as China and India and some of the

Column: 701

Southeast Asian countries, our business cost is still on the high side.  We should try our best to reduce rental by 20% and also give maybe 10% rebate on the PUB charges for the factories.  This is very important.  We have adjusted the CPF and wage cost, but the entire business cost, factory rental overheads and other expenses are also very important.  When we reduce the rental we should consider one thing, that is, Singapore dollar's conversion rate to another currency is quite high.  One Singapore dollar is equivalent to 4.8 reminbi (yuan).  Of course, we cannot reduce our level to that of China or Hong Kong, but we should try to keep it down so that we could be more competitive and attract more foreign investors to come here. Column: 702

for our people.  So, this is "killing two birds with one stone".

Column: 703

we consider the exceptionally low total fertility rate, the Government has little choice but to step in to help.   But as I have said, giving birth to children is not an easy thing. Our parents would encourage us to have more children. To them, one more child means simply adding one bowl and a pair of chopsticks.  The additional cost is not very much.  In a big family, we look after one another.  We, in fact, compete with one another on the number of children to have.  Every year, we had at least one new baby in the big family, and it came very naturally.  My three elder brothers and an elder sister have an average of 4 children each. Now that they have all moved out, all forming small families, myself, my younger brother and younger sister have an average of 2 children only, so naturally the family size has reduced.

Column: 704

would have an agreement not to have a baby for the next three or five years, and then at the age of 35 when they begin to have this intention to have children, they may not even be able to conceive.  So we should encourage our people to marry early and to have baby early.  So this is the first thing the MCDS should do.  I hope that we should have seminars and campaigns to encourage our people to marry early and to have children early.

So, this will involve the Ministry of Health.  Some young couples wanted to have children but could not conceive.  They go for medical treatment.  If they go to a consultant, it would cost them a lot of money. So this is a Ministry of Health's problem. I hope the Ministry of Health would help these young couples.

Column: 705

seriously rethink the suggestion to extend the maternity leave.

 

     Maybe the Government should consider setting up "nanny centres" to look after the new babies.   They can engage nannies to help the new mothers look after their babies, and also to do some of the household chores during the maternity period.   This would also provide some job opportunities for our women folk.   If you cannot find someone who is competent in this, maybe the Ministry of Manpower could introduce a B (baby) pass so that we can allow foreign nannies with the competence to come here on a temporary basis to take up this job of  looking after the babies.

     Fourthly, I would like to talk about CPF.  After giving birth, new mothers could not make use of their Medisave to pay for 100% of the medical fees.   Some of these young mothers do not have enough cash, but they do have CPF.   We should help these young mothers by allowing them to use their CPF to pay 100% of their medical fees in order to solve the problem of cashflow.

 

     Fifthly, we should look into childcare and baby care service.   Nowadays, women are facing problems with baby care.   After giving birth, they have two

Column: 706

months of maternity leave.   After that, both the husband and wife will have to go out and work.   If they can afford a maid, then it is not so bad.  But what happens if they cannot afford to have a maid?   This is when baby-care service comes in handy.  In every housing estate, there should be at least one baby care service centre, so that these young mothers could go back to work after their maternity leave and the babies would have a good environment to be looked after well.

This is a long-term problem.   So I hope that the Ministry of Education would look into this matter. Children staying within two kilometres of the schools should be given places there.

 

Column: 707

     Seventhly, on media publication.   Recently, if we look at the newspapers, we can see a lot of advertisements about slimming.   Everybody likes to be beautiful.   I think slimming is something that everybody is looking forward to.  But if there are too many advertisements, when women look at these advertisements, they get worried.   They say, "Now that I have a child, I will lose my figure.   How can I compete with all these young slim people?"  I hope that something could be done to prevent  these slimming advertisements from painting ugly pictures of pregnant women, thereby  causing some sort of psychological burden on pregnancy.

I hope that the inter-ministry committee will set up a special task force to counsel women, who want to go for abortion, to find out the reasons for abortion.   Is it because of financial problem?   Is it because of family dispute or some other pressures like work

Column: 708

pressure, family pressure or other reasons?    I think if we were to have a thorough understanding of the reasons why pregnant women go for abortions, we would be able to achieve some good results, ie, reducing the number of abortions.

 

     The other group is the unmarried young women.   I think this is also a serious matter which we should pay attention to.   To my understanding, about two-thirds of the abortions are from the married women and one-third from the unmarried women.   I think the committee should look into this matter and find out why they go for abortions.   Maybe we should be able to save more babies and this is a direct channel for them to save the babies.   Now, we have 37,000 babies.   If we can save the 13,000 babies from abortion each year, we would have attained our target of 50,000.

 

     Finally, we want to encourage our people to have more babies.   This is not something that can be done overnight.   This is a long-term job that is to be undertaken by many Ministries.   Eventually, we have to inculcate in our young citizens the responsibility of having children and also on the correct family values.   So, on the one hand, we have to give them incentives and help them to solve their problems; on the other hand, we should also inculcate in them the proper values through education.   I suggest that the Government start a "Happy Family Movement".  This movement is not just to encourage every family to have children, but for our grassroots and community organisations to inculcate in our people, through education, the values and responsibility of having children.   We should send this message to every citizen so that they can understand the future problems of our society and the importance of having children.   I think if everybody has a good understanding of this problem, then all the other problems could be solved.

that in some instances we have not looked at who wants babies, people who are trying hard to become parents to assess how we can help them along the way.  Earlier, Dr Michael Lim has elaborated on the ART of trying to have children.  I will look at when the biological struggle to have a child fails, what are the other options and how can the state help in this case.  

Column: 710

Parent wannabes can be persuaded to adopt, and right now the process is becoming less painful, with MCDS setting up two VWOs to look into this area.  The question here is:  can we further enhance the easing of this adoption scheme and allow desperate couples to get their children from overseas or locally as soon as possible?

     Also, likewise the extension of the Pioneer Incentives from 10 years to 15 years, I think, is a very timely move, in the case of MNCs moving out of Singapore.  And this will help to keep them here, it is not just about buying time.  It will also encourage MNCs to upgrade their activities into higher value-added activities.  Besides, it will also encourage projects with long gestation to

Column: 721

locate in Singapore.  So both these incentives will help Singapore position itself as a hub for manufacturing and services.  Because to be an effective hub, we need a wide corporate base.  So we need to attract more companies to Singapore as well as to continue to retain those companies already rooted here.

 

     I like to move on to financial services because this is of great interest to me.  I am very happy that in fact this received most attention, except that it has got obscured by the babies.  Budget 2004 introduced many incentives in the financial services sector.  I agree with the Economic Review Committee's recommendation

to develop the high-end processing services for this sector because we simply cannot compete with countries like India for mass processing.  On the other hand, this is not something that only we can do.  So, we cannot rest on the notion that our competitors will not go up the value chain and also do this business now or in the near future.

Column: 722

said, and it is a bit of a non-event because the incentives have not been announced.  We will have to wait until National Day to hear about them.  As Ms Braema Mathiaparanam said, this is a refreshing change, I suppose because this affords a wonderful opportunity for the Government to receive feedback as well as suggestions.  Much has already been given, and I would like to reiterate some of the points made.  I think it is important to recognise the problems of affordability and about how burdensome it is to raise children.  Put it that way, it does not sound very nice.  And also the problems of beyond tax incentives, of how to make work easier and also less stressful for the couples.  In particular, I would like more attention or help being put in the way of infant care as well as after-school care.

     We have just heard the voice of business earlier from hon. Member, Mrs Fang Ai Lian.  Allow me to talk a little about strong society from the socio-economic point of view. 

 

     To me, Sir, this is the right Budget for the right time. To agree with that statement, one needs to see the Budget in the context of what has been offered and achieved by way of the few previous budgets, particularly since the financial crisis of the late 90s.  For those who look at the Budget in anticipation of more personal goodies, I agree with some of the feedback I have heard from my grassroots that it did not provide much excitement.

Column: 724

our human capital is one key resource we have to do our best to develop.  Thus, I see the Government's intentions to raise university fees with some concern.  So do I worry about healthcare affordability in our efforts to build a strong society, what more a greying one.

Column: 725

burden on the heads of the fresh undergraduates and their families.

 

     I would not be surprised if that also contributes to the larger concern to delay having their babies, let alone to have more bundles of joy when discharging loans still unpaid.  If fees need to go up, requiring more to resort to loans, perhaps the Government could also consider allowing an incentive scheme where those graduates with such loans who marry early and have children would benefit from the baby bonus schemes, eg, a rebate on their outstanding loans.

Column: 726

families, but reality is different.  Of course, we must do more to bring about this sense of shared responsibilities, as this will also be an important factor whether we succeed in promoting bigger family size.  And it is more than just a question of affordability.  It is also about quality of life, the pressures and demands on our time, and whether we could provide the kind of time necessary to ensure quality time for the family.  Like other Members of the House, I also empathise with Mr Lim's unenviable task, but I am sure Minister Lim will not leave any stone unturned to ensure that this fundamental about procreation and a better replacement rate is a success.

Column: 727

kiasu Singaporeans can be, many would feel it is better to be cautious than to risk high charges.

 

     Means testing sounds equitable but, being new, I am glad to see the Government agreeing to "proceed cautiously".  MOH needs to work out a system that is sustainable and this will be possible with time and experience.  The Government must ensure that this means testing will not end up being seen as "mean". 

 

     Flexibility must be its test, as services cover a wide range of inpatient care to surgery to specialist outpatient.  There is also the need to differentiate from the ordinary observation ward to the ICU, with or without complication, no matter how low the chances of complications surface. 

 

     The heart-wrenching case of filial children wanting to show gratitude to their father and placing him for observation in class A, ending up with complications and weeks in ICU and a $170,000 bill a year back, would be a case worth looking at.  Indeed, for fear of such a situation

or complications, there would be many Singaporeans who would prefer to be prudent in going for lower class treatment and not because they want to abuse the subsidy system.

We note that while 12,000 jobs were created in the second half of 2003, 30,000 jobs were lost in the first half.

The deficit has had a dent on that Singapore spirit.
